HEADLINE: Let Them Eat Crow 

BYLINE:  By Rob Walker; Rob Walker is a contributing writer for Money and Slate.com.

 BODY:
 THE DINNER CLUB
How the Masters of the Internet Universe
Rode the Rise and Fall
of the Greatest Boom in History.
By Shannon Henry.
288 pp. New York: The Free Press. $26.
 AS a contributing factor in the 1990's technology-stock bubble, denial is underrated. Many of us now prefer to think of the entrepreneurs and the gurus who made such elaborate promises just a few years ago as a bunch of charlatans and crooks who set out to trick the world in a huge confidence game. Somehow this seems more satisfying than concluding that these people really believed what they were saying, and were simply dead wrong. The charlatan theory is attractive because it allows the rest of us to be victims; to accept that the peddlers of the sunniest version of the Internet dream were simply blinkered by their own fantasies is to admit that those who bought the dream were in denial, too. 
But denial must have been thick in the air in November 2000, when a Washington Post reporter named Shannon Henry began attending the dinner meetings of the Capital Investors. These 25 or so technology entrepreneurs from the Washington area had amassed huge fortunes, mostly in stock, and decided to form a sort of hybrid kaffeeklatsch and investment club. The gatherings would channel knowledge, contacts and money to the deserving next generation of start-ups and generally "create a force." Members included Steve Case, now the chairman of AOL Time Warner; Michael Saylor, C.E.O. of the software company MicroStrategy; Alex Mandl, the former president of AT&T; and John Sidgmore, an executive at WorldCom. 
Henry persuaded these "masters of the Internet universe," as her book's subtitle has it, to let her into the sanctum to record what happens when such minds meet. That November 2000 dinner coincided with the Florida chadmire that dragged out the end of the last presidential election, and we listen in as the gang pompously discusses how they would solve the problem. In general, they seem to believe that the country would be better off if it were run by one of their number.
Of course, there are guys at my neighborhood bar who reach a very similar conclusion every Friday night. In neither case is the discourse leading up to this epiphany very enlightening. The only thing that makes the high rollers' blather slightly more interesting is that by the time of this dinner, the turbocharged economy that had created them was already cracking up, a turn of events as obvious as the plunging Nasdaq, which had been bleeding for many months. Many of these men would soon be lucky to continue running their own companies, let alone the United States government.
According to Henry, the 1990's boom spawned "a new ideology" among the instantly wealthy -- they were "richer, younger and more idealistic than those who amassed wealth in the 1980's," and they craved the instant gratification of deploying their money "in ways that might change something, now." So at each Capital Investors dinner, a handful of young entrepreneurs would get a chance to make a pitch for money, assuming they had good enough answers as the titans quizzed them between courses. 
Reality set in somewhat belatedly over the course of the year that Henry attended these sessions. Probably the best scene in the book is an April 2001 dinner at the Georgetown Club, where a young man named Reggie Aggarwal, who had earlier wangled one capital injection from the group, strikes out in his attempt to get a second financial commitment. When he leaves the room one Capital Investor says, in so many words, "Reggie is full of it, isn't he?" Here's the moment when the denial finally lifted. All it lacks is someone else blurting, "My God, we all are!" 
This actually points to a big problem for "The Dinner Club": why should we care about these people? Henry writes that she "wanted to show that this technology boom and bust did not occur only in the confines of Silicon Valley." Since there's little substance to the dinner party scenes, we also get a thorough history of the Washington area tech community. There is a chapter on the Nextel co-founder Mark Warner's successful run for governor of Virginia. And there's a rehashing of the sorry tale of Saylor, the blowhard C.E.O. of MicroStrategy who is best known for comparing himself to Mother Teresa and for the massive collapse of his company's share price (from a high of $333 to about $1, as Henry mentions four times).
The biggest names in the group are Steve Case and Marc Andreessen, but neither of them seems to be around much during the period the book covers -- and actually Andreessen was only a temporary Washington area resident who soon headed back to the Valley. Late in the book we find that even one of the Capital Investors' principal architects has quietly moved to Cleveland, citing Washington's "pretentiousness." 
Along the way, Henry -- who according to this book's dust jacket is "widely labeled the 'dot-com diva' " -- is surprisingly nonjudgmental when the C.E.O. of Proxicom declares that one of the "lessons" he learned was that he was right to start selling his stock immediately. Or when the same guy complains that the managers of the company that bought his didn't give him the inside scoop about earnings problems before he bought several million dollars' worth of stock. ("Had he known about the missed earnings, he could have bought at another time," Henry writes dispassionately.) Or when Mandl, who failed to keep his telecom start-up from going bankrupt, says that next time around he plans to "control the board" and "regularly sell off shares."
As for the 18 new companies the group backed, several flamed out completely, and not one had produced any return on the group's investment by the end of 2001. This is hardly a surprise, since the Capital Investors seemed to think about their portfolio for no more than a few minutes a month. The group may have come together thinking they'd be world-changing Renaissance men -- one member jets to Colombia to lecture a rebel leader on the wonders of capitalism -- but they come across mostly as spoiled dilettantes. And surely no more than a footnote to the bigger story of the 1990's.
It's odd that the Capital Investors would have agreed to let a journalist in on what amounted to an ill-considered hobby in the closing months of 2000. But maybe it's even more odd that someone would want in when the action was so clearly moving in a different direction. Perhaps all concerned still figured that the club's members, against all odds, could "change something" while the new-economy idea crumbled around them. Talk about denial.

HEADLINE: The Year in Ideas; 
Intellectual Magnet Cities

BYLINE:  By Blaine Harden 

 BODY:
American cities used to become rich and important by attracting high-energy, low-skilled workers from abroad or from farm states. Now they do the same thing by luring brainy young people away from less livable American cities. Austin, San Francisco and Seattle are sparkling with newly arrived smarties who recently fled Cleveland, Harrisburg and St. Louis. 
 The 2000 census, which shows a clear correlation between a city's prosperity and its attractiveness to college graduates, suggests a new, winner-take-all pattern in urban growth. A handful of cities are quickly moving away from the pack in their ability to attract and retain workers with college degrees. In the top 100 metro areas, the 25 cities that began the 90's with the highest percentage of college graduates ended the decade with even more. The highfliers saw the educated share of their population jump by 6 percentage points -- twice the average growth of the other 75 cities. 
 Winning seems to feed on itself, as cities like San Francisco, Boston and San Diego have become more than just good places to find a high-paying job. They are cool places to hang out, with gourmet food, great live music and an abundance of well-spoken, well-dressed singles looking for sex and marriage.
Losing, too, feeds on itself. Cities like El Paso, Gary and Hartford are dreary places with diminishing night life and an acute shortage of upwardly mobile romantic prospects. The good catches with college degrees have high-tailed it to Raleigh-Durham or Denver. (It is hard for demographers to tweeze out patterns in huge cities like New York or L.A. They gain and lose millions of smart people in ways that do not lend themselves to easy analysis.)
There is a downside for the winner cities -- chronic inequality. Cities with the highest percentage of college graduates also tend to attract low-skill, low-wage newcomers to work in the yuppie service economy. They make coffee, mow lawns and mind babies, but have low salaries, poor benefits and little upward mobility. They also tend to be segregated, not by race but by income, from the highfliers they serve.
Yet there is no mistaking the dollar value of luring in ever-more-smart young things. The Austin American-Statesman, in an analysis of nine years of income-tax records, found that 10,000 more people moved to Austin from Dallas-Fort Worth than moved in the other direction. Those who came to ever-smarter Austin were better paid than those who left for Dallas. The result: an annual income gain for Austin of half a billion dollars. Blaine Harden

HEADLINE: The Year in Ideas; 
Forced Transparency

BYLINE:  By Blaine Harden 

 BODY:
In poor countries blessed with oil, revenue from oil has a way of making most people poorer. The pattern is so pervasive and has been going on for so long that it has a catchy slogan: the paradox of plenty.
 No place has been more paradoxical for more years than Angola. It is potentially the richest country in Africa, with huge reserves of offshore oil and a population of just 12 million. Oil money, though, has bought decades of war, while giving Angolans a terrible standard of living. Although the war ended this spring, it's still not clear where the money is going (or even how much there is). In the past five years, $4 billion has vanished; meanwhile, the world spends about $200 million a year to feed poor Angolans. To break this cycle, in Angola and elsewhere, a simple idea has emerged this year. It also has a catchy slogan: Publish What You Pay. 
 The World Bank backs the idea, as does George Soros, the financier and human rights crusader, as do 70 private aid agencies around the world. The Publish What You Pay coalition prods major companies to declare how much money they give governments in order to extract oil and minerals. If citizens know how much money comes in, they can, at the very least, figure out how much is stolen. Forcing transparency on corrupt governments would increase pressure on leaders to spend more on schools, hospitals and roads -- and might motivate citizens to toss out known thieves. 
Tony Blair, the British prime minister, gave the idea a boost this fall by calling on all companies involved in oil and mineral extraction to voluntarily announce how much they pay. But the Publish What You Pay coalition wants more. They want regulators of the world's richest stock markets, like the Securities and Exchange Commission, to compel oil companies to declare net annual payments to countries like Angola. None currently do.
Most oil-producing states hate this idea. And oil companies fear losing billion-dollar concessions to competitors that will keep their mouths shut. This is not an irrational fear. When BP announced last year that it would publish its payments to Angola, the government threatened to cut the company off unless it "scrupulously respects" confidentiality laws.
In all this, the Bush administration has been noticeable for not taking a leadership role. Forty percent of Angola's oil is exported to the United States. blaine hardend to cut the company off unless it "scrupulously respects" confidentiality laws.
In all this, the Bush administration, has been noticeable for not taking a leadership role. forty percent of Angolas oil is exported to the United States. Blaine Harden

HEADLINE: The Year in Ideas; 
Hybrid That Gets 239 M.P.G.

BYLINE:  By Stephen Mihm 

 BODY:
The You have to hand it to those hyperefficient Germans. While American auto manufacturers keep wailing about how devastating it would be if the government raised fuel-economy standards by one mile per gallon, the clever engineers at Volkswagen went ahead and unveiled a car this year that gets 239 m.p.g. 
 Think how a car that gets 239 m.p.g. would stack up against our much-beloved gas guzzlers in a hypothetical "race" between the VW and an S.U.V. that gets 15 m.p.g. Starting in New York City, each vehicle is given -- let's be generous here -- 50 gallons of fuel to make a cross-country trip. While the S.U.V. would grind to a stop outside not-so-beautiful Gary, Ind., the 239 m.p.g. car could go all the way to Los Angeles and then have enough to go back to New York, back to L.A. once more, back to New York yet again and still have enough left over to make it to Chicago. 
 The VW prototype, a sleek black two-seater with a single gull-wing door, looks like a cross between a Lamborghini and the Batmobile. It was built, in the understated words of one company spokesman, "to show how state-of-the-art technology can be used to reduce fuel consumption and still come up with a safe, usable and roadworthy vehicle." 
Several elements contribute to the car's performance. An ultraefficient diesel engine captures and stores energy when the driver hits the brakes, converting it to electricity that is then used to help propel the vehicle. The aerodynamic exterior cuts drag: wheels are sheathed in carbon fiber, and the car's designers dispensed with exterior mirrors, replacing them with tiny video cameras that display images on liquid-crystal screens on the dashboard. 
It also helps that the car is extraordinarily light. The engine weighs a mere 57 pounds, and a host of magnesium, titanium and aluminum components help keep the total mass down. But don't worry about safety. With its carbon-fiber composite exterior, crash tubes and air bags, the car has a safety rating equivalent to a racecar's. Though it may not go as fast as a Ferrari -- it cruises at 75 miles per hour -- it's fast enough for most drivers. Volkswagen doesn't currently have plans to mass-produce the vehicle, but it may harvest the car's innovative technologies for future versions of its more mainstream models. Stephen Mihm

HEADLINE: The Year in Ideas; 
Whitelisting

BYLINE:  By Marshall Sella 

 BODY:
The dream of e-mail has always been that of an open world. It was to be a revved-up cognate of the telephone and, hearkening to a simpler age, shouting across the village square. With a few keyboard strokes, Jimmy or Timmy in Brisbane, Australia, could easily shout out to another Jimmy or Timmy in Sandusky, Ohio. Those days, however, may soon be gone -- thanks to whitelisting, a new technology that allows users to keep bothersome strangers out of their e-mail in box. 
 The primary reason e-mail is becoming a closed system is spam, the dreaded electronic junk mail that floods in under the guise of deceptive subject headings like "Great seeing you last week" or "I found those pictures you wanted!" In recent years, spam has become an annoyance pandemic. The average Web user gets more than 2,000 unsolicited messages annually. Businesses, especially, have suffered. According to one study, managers spend 10 minutes of every hour being forced to read about low mortgage rates, how to increase the size of certain body parts and the like. These are hardly welcome new components of a well-oiled economy.
 Whitelisting technology helps you to filter out this chaff by permitting you to receive e-mail only from people and Internet vendors you specify. (The name is a play on blacklisting, in which people on a specified list are ostracized.) Most major e-mail providers now include some kind of filtering service. America Online, Microsoft and Yahoo!, for example, have incorporated whitelist guards into their systems -- with varying success. AOL itself has a five-option smorgasbord, which includes blocking just about everything or allowing only certain domain names (say, Amazon.com). But whitelisting in its purest form -- granting access solely to those whose exact addresses you know at this moment -- has proved to be a bit too black and white for most consumers. People don't want the spam, but they do want to hear from that old high-school sweetheart. 
 Efforts are now being made to gray things up a bit, to create technology that probes deeper, in order to avoid banishing as-yet-unknown e-mail messages you might actually want to read. An e-mail security firm called MessageLabs has enlisted heuristics technology, identifying what it calls "spam DNA" instead of going with the all-or-nothing approach. This is probably a good thing. E-mail may be the Wild West of communication -- a virtual seedy saloon -- but most of us like to have a drink once in a while. Marshall Sella

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 12-15-02: QUESTIONS FOR JEFFREY SACHS; 
Poor Man's Economist

BYLINE:  By Amy Barrett 

 BODY:
Q: This year you moved from the Center for International Development at Harvard to Columbia and started the Earth Institute, which is dedicated to the idea of sustainable development. What is that?
 Sustainable development means rising living standards for everybody in a way that's not going to destroy our ecosystems, cause mass extinctions and add to enormous problems in climate or water scarcity. The links between the physical environment and the economic environment are much more profound than economists have recognized. If they really want to get to the core of what's happening in Africa, they had better start understanding AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and nitrogen-depleted soil. These are important phenomena that help to explain why the poorest countries are not achieving economic progress. 
 That seems like common sense. Why do you even need the idea of sustainable development?
In academia, the scientists and the policy types rarely deal with one another directly, especially on problems of the poor. The idea of the Earth Institute is to focus not on the disciplines but on the problems and to bring together five main areas in an intensive dialogue: the earth sciences, ecological science, engineering, public health and the social sciences with a heavy dose of economics. 
The term sustainable development showed up in the 80's, and it wasn't very popular. Why not find another, more marketable, catch phrase?
I resisted the term also because a lot of people said what sustainable development means is that the rich have to cut their living standards sharply to make room for the poor. But my own analysis doesn't suggest that the reason that poor people are poor is that rich people are rich. I think rich people are rich because they have developed technology successfully to address a lot of challenges and because they were lucky enough not to have some of the ecological barriers that the poor have. 
But under the idea of sustainable development, won't Americans have to cut back on their consumption in some way in order to not deplete the planet?
We have to cut back on the amount of carbon that we are putting in the atmosphere, but that doesn't necessarily mean that we have to cut back on our living standards. If you develop technology that can capture the carbon, you can have your consumption and your climate too. 
At some point, though, won't we simply have to stop consuming so much?
Actually, one of the surprises of the last couple of centuries is that we are not running out of stuff. Almost every commodity has gone down significantly in price in the last hundred years. Stuff is not driving our economy. More and more of what we do is in bits and information services. 
You have said that a lot of your ideas came from experience on the ground in poor countries, rather than in the classroom. Are there a lot of theories in economics that just don't work when you go out into the world?
Or are completely irrelevant in a particular context, because what might be important in one place may be irrelevant in another place. Differential diagnosis is critical. You have to be open to the wide range of things that can go wrong in the world. 
Many economists are still very skeptical of the idea of sustainable development. How are you going to sell it?
I'm on my way to China this month to meet the Chinese leadership. In January, I'll be traveling to India. Yesterday, I was on video conference with a number of ministers of health from Latin America. 
So you are a global economic consultant.
Well, I call it an adviser, but yes, I've been doing that for a number of years. 
Columbia has given you an $8 million town house for the use of the Earth Institute. Is there a part of your new job that will be fun, giving dinner parties for dignitaries, maybe having Bono stop by? 
Of course. I adore the work I do with Bono. He's one of the great people on the planet. To have advised the pope, to be engaged with Kofi Annan -- I think our world's greatest political leader -- it's a joy beyond anything I could have hoped for. To have pulled out of the papal residence in a van with Bono and have the mobs chasing behind us, like in a Beatles movie -- it's fun, I have to say.
Did you feel like a rock star?
I leaned over to him, and I said, "Look, they always do that with macroeconomists." And he looked at me, like, "Yeah, right." Amy Barrett

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
An Anthem Frosted With Irony

BYLINE:  By BERNARD HOLLAND

 BODY:
THE first impression of "White Christmas" is motion. Leaning gently forward, unencumbered, each phrase is in perfect balance with the others, as if a hidden spring in one were propelling the words and music to the next. "White Christmas" travels light, unnecessary baggage stripped away.
 A Cole Porter song teases with double meanings. George Gershwin's "Our Love Is Here to Stay" enchants us with a Schubertian symmetry. Both men invite the ear to apply the brakes gently and to reflect on what has been heard. "White Christmas" is not like that. Irving Berlin may have been a man of large personal insecurities, but the best song he ever wrote shows no doubt and no need for second thoughts. 
 "White Christmas" -- as Jody Rosen's new book of the same name (from Scribner) tells us -- began life in 1937 with its tongue in cheek. The verse describes a poolside Christmas Eve in Los Angeles and the incongruities of a yuletide set at 80 degrees and dipped in chlorinated water; only after the introductory ironies does the famous chorus follow. After "White Christmas" became World War II's national anthem of American homesickness, when Bing Crosby's recording became as essential to G.I. battle gear as hand grenades and C rations, Berlin had the initial verse suppressed.It had already absented itself from "Holiday Inn," Crosby's snowbound movie of 1942, for obvious meteorological reasons, and from his recording of the same year.
Everyone, Berlin included, was staggered by the song's success and profitability. He had been writing hits since 1911 ("Alexander's Ragtime Band"), and 35 years later there was fertility enough to produce "Annie, Get Your Gun" on Broadway. Hundreds of successes in between had made him millions, but if Berlin had abandoned all other rights, he and his family could have lived in wild luxury on the returns of one song alone. Mr. Rosen reports that the Crosby version has sold 31 million copies.
"White Christmas," of course, traffics in nostalgia. It is the singer standing in one time and place thinking about another time and place. That second time and place never existed, at least in the terms in which it is remembered. Berlin was an immigrant Jew from Siberia, writing about a Christian celebration foreign to his past. The Christmas of "White Christmas" is about snow and sleigh bells, not the birth of the son of God in a heat-drenched and dusty Middle Eastern town.
The contradictions more or less put Berlin's Christmas on an equal footing with that of his gentile fellow Americans. Indeed, the present-day merger of rural New England winter by way of Currier & Ives with Dickensian urban scenes reminds us that Christmas is a newer religion's superimposition of itself on a midwinter feast that reaches much farther back in history than the glad tidings reported from Bethlehem 2,000 years ago. The music and rituals of Christmases past have become delightful and touching ornaments, but the season's enormous economic engine of productivity and sales makes the heathen aspect of Dec. 25 a little overpowering next to its more recent worshipful side.
"White Christmas" is melancholy but straightforward, submerging its minor-key deviousness until we forget that it is there. The beginning is a swirl of clustered half-steps. The 18th century called this kind of gesture a "turn" and wrote it as an S turned on its side. Mr. Rosen's book has nice descriptions of Berlin's musical secrets, including the long, unexpected held note on the word "bright," and the brief final phrase that rights and restores an equilibrium suddenly under threat.
There is nothing bitter in the melancholy of "White Christmas." Its wistfulness may not be profound, but the grace of its shape and movement is another story. Educated on the mean streets of turn-of-the-20th-century popular music, Berlin wrote songs for sale. To bring in money, they had to reach out unequivocally to as many people as possible. Berlin was "a public songwriter," Mr. Rosen tells us. He once said: "A good song embodies the feeling of the mob. A songwriter is not much more than a mirror which reflects those feelings."
There are two paths to musical immortality. One leads to a Valhalla peopled by Beethoven and the like. The other penetrates the collective consciousness of ordinary people.
How many intelligent listeners still believe that Dvorak plucked "Goin' Home" from folklore and inserted it in his "New World" Symphony? Actually, it was the other way around. Germany's famous national anthem, "Deutschland Uber Alles," is not the traditional public artifact it is often believed to be but music by Haydn, laboriously fashioned (as we know from a pile of rejected sketches) in his "Emperor" String Quartet. Put four Austrians and as many liters of wine together, and by the end of the evening you will hear "Der Lindenbaum," sung by men unaware that they are in the midst of a Schubert art song. Grieg's music created a Norwegian folk heritage out of thin air. Solitary composers have manufactured a lot of music since taken over by the public and submerged into everyday usage.
Today "White Christmas" doesn't seem to be by anybody. It's too much ours. It initially prospered among a military audience sweltering on Guadalcanal or frozen in bombed-out Belgian towns, but opportunism does not account for the song's immediate and unshakable place in everyone's heart. "White Christmas" speaks with great beauty to everyone. Berlin himself called it "the greatest song anybody ever wrote." A hard sell, perhaps, but with high-quality goods.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.; 
Plants That Block a Terrace View

 BODY:
 Q. We are shareholders who live on the top floor of a nine-story co-op. Each unit on our floor has sliding glass doors to an undivided terrace. There are no permanent physical structures that note the boundary lines of each shareholder's part of the terrace, but we have marked our lines on both sides with low rectangular flower pots. 
 Just recently, our neighbor to the right placed huge planters with four- to five-foot bushy shrubs along his terrace boundary line. Now, when we sit in our living room, we can no longer see the view of Manhattan and New York Harbor. Are there any regulations about impairing a shareholder's view in a co-op? . . . Leroy Smith, Staten Island.

A. Richard Klein, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that he is not aware of any state or city regulations governing the height of plants placed on terraces.
And, Mr. Klein said, there is nothing in state or city law that makes it unlawful for one property owner to block another property owner's views, provided the first property owner is not violating any building or zoning regulations.
"Being that this is a co-op, however," Mr. Klein said, "the corporation's proprietary lease and house rules would be the first place to look to see if the corporation has imposed any restrictions." Many proprietary leases, he said, contain a provision prohibiting any "planting, fences, structures or lattices" on the terraces, balconies or roof of the building without the prior written approval of the co-op.
While the house rules of many co-ops also contain certain restrictions and conditions regarding planting on terraces and balconies -- such as making sure that the plantings are standing on supports at least two inches above the surface -- he has never seen a rule restricting the height of the plants. 
Mr. Klein said that if there are no lease or house rules regarding blocking shareholders' views by planting on terraces, the letter writer could petition the board to come up with some kind of policy that will allow the shareholders to have plantings while not interfering with other shareholders' views. 
"I would suggest that Mr. Smith speak to his neighbor to see if they can work something out," Mr. Klein said. "It is possible that the neighbor might not even be aware that he is obstructing Mr. Smith's view."

A Rent Increase For a Renovation

Q. My landlord recently renovated all the bathrooms in my building and is seeking a large rent increase from the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal. The quality of many of the new fixtures is inferior to the original equipment. The bathtubs are smaller, shallower and cheaply made, and the bathroom doors and frames are quite flimsy. Is there any law requiring landlords to replace items with fixtures of equal quality? . . . Tim Smith, Manhattan.

A. Joel E. Abramson, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer, said it appears that the letter writer is referring to a major-capital-improvement increase the landlord has requested for renovating all the bathrooms in the building.
While the law that allows such increases does not specifically address the quality of the fixtures used in a renovation, Mr. Abramson said, it does require the landlord to improve the building and it does give tenants an opportunity to submit objections to the landlord's application. 
He said that the tenants have 30 days from the time the state agency notifies them of the landlord's application to inform the agency of their concerns. The agency will then take those concerns into consideration in deciding whether the increase is warranted. 
For such a buildingwide increase, a landlord is allowed to raise the total monthly rent in the building by 1/84th of the cost of the improvements. An individual tenant's share of the increase is pro rated on a per-room basis.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN IDEAS; 
Climate Jumping

BYLINE:  By William Speed Weed 

 BODY:
On April 3, the high temperature in New York City was a balmy 77 degrees -- a full 17 degrees warmer than the previous day. New Yorkers were delighted; many wore shorts. But what if the earth's whole climate system were to snap warm like that? It would be anything but delightful. Imagine the global temperature spiking 17 degrees in a decade. Enough polar ice could melt to cause oceans to surge over New York, Amsterdam and Bangladesh faster than people could build dikes or relocate to higher ground. A global warming snap could wreak havoc on regional weather patterns: rain forests would dry up, tundras would melt. Imagine a centuries-long, Sahara-hot drought setting upon the West Coast and withering crops (and Californians). 
 This dire situation bears little resemblance to the global-warming picture, currently in vogue among policy makers, of a slow, steady warming that creeps along imperceptibly year by year. This picture is dead wrong, according to a National Academy of Sciences study published this year. Climate change often isn't gradual. It's sudden and ferocious. When it happens, we won't have time to adjust. 
 The report, "Abrupt Climate Change: Inevitable Surprises," collates a mass of geological evidence showing that the earth's climate system is a jumpy beast: long, dormant spells are overturned suddenly by drastic events. Instead of smoothly transitioning over 10,000 years from ice age to warm era, the earth jumps from one "regime" to another in just a few years. For instance, 11,500-year-old ice cores taken from Greenland show that annual precipitation doubled in three years and that the annual mean temperature jumped 14 degrees in just 10 years. "That means a third to half of the warming that took place between the last ice age and today all happened in one decade," says Richard Alley, the Penn State geologist who presided over the study. Two dozen such climate jumps have occurred in the last 100,000 years.
As for what causes abrupt climate change, Alley says that "nobody know what the triggers are." Does that let us off the hook with greenhouse gas emissions? Not at all. "The climate has changed most drastically when something was forcing it, like a change in the earth's orbit around the sun," says Alley. "Our emissions today are definitely forcing the climate." William Nordhaus, a Yale economist who also worked on the report, says that the impact of gradual global warming would be relatively modest. But the "abrupt stuff is more dangerous," he says. "What we're triggering is in a sense irreversible. . . . If we flip into that mode, it may be like that for 5,000 years." William Speed Weed

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN IDEAS; 
Coming-Of-Age-In-Eastern-Europe Novel, The

BYLINE:  By Taylor Antrim 

 BODY:
Among the year's best novels, a trio of debuts -- Gary Shteyngart's "Russian Debutante's Handbook," Arthur Phillips's "Prague" and John Beckman's "Winter Zoo" -- all shared the same basic plot: young man graduates from college circa 1990, undergoes crisis and rushes into the warm embrace of Eastern Europe. Readers who themselves hit Prague, Budapest or Cracow in the early 90's winced in self-recognition. But for Shteyngart, Phillips and Beckman, post-Communist Eastern Europe isn't just a hipster destination; it's a free market in the raw, a playground for Americans on the make. Their heroes establish a model of self-becoming that should pain those anxiously mining today's Wall Street for gold. 
 Another Eastern European pilgrimage novel this year, Jonathan Safran Foer's "Everything Is Illuminated," gave us a young man's search for his ancestral roots. That's a more traditional literary mode of self-discovery; so is sex or drink or a general questioning of authority, either on the road ("On the Road"), in or out of school ("The Catcher in the Rye," "The Rachel Papers") or in a racy, cosmopolitan milieu ("Less Than Zero," "Bright Lights, Big City"). While there is plenty of sex and drink in Shteyngart, Phillips and Beckman, it's the financial exploitation, investment land grabs and Ponzi schemes that really drive these stories along. 
 Take Shteyngart's Vladimir Girshkin, born in the Soviet Union, educated at a Midwestern college, bewildered and, as he puts it, "half-formed" in 1993 Manhattan. He escapes to the fictional Eastern European capital of Prava and, through a phony investment scheme, begins fleecing its young, moneyed expatriates with self-actualizing zeal. "To be rich in my own milieu," he says, "to partake in the economic rebirth of my own part of the world, why if that's not part of my narrative, what the hell is?" Likewise Charles Gabor of "Prague" (which actually takes place in Budapest) teams up with a fellow ex-pat, John Price, to privatize a small press run by a Hungarian family and sell it off to a global media conglomerate. Back home, Gabor and Price would be feckless Americans; in Budapest, they're coming-of-age capitalists, intent on self-determination and a slice of the free-market pie. Then there's Beckman's Gurney. During the fall of 1990, he struggles (with meager success) to bed all the American women in Cracow. After scamming a fortune from a Western-backed casino, he stages an orgy in which his friends dub him Midas and kowtow, unclothed, at his feet. His thoughts run a mantra: "Currency, currency, currency. . . ."
Wit, irony and some irrepressibly likable protagonists save these novels from sanctioning the superficiality they describe. Still, in a headline year of corporate fraud, the books remind us just how strongly we've come to identify economic entitlement with national identity. Getting something for nothing: it's how Americans grow up. Taylor Antrim

HEADLINE: The Year in Ideas; 
Pokemon Hegemon

BYLINE:  By Margaret Talbot 

 BODY:
If you are the parent of an American child, then you may well have noticed how Japanese our kid culture has become. No set of images has dominated childish desires quite so handily over the last five years or so as the amalgams of cuteness and power in the Japanese-made cartoons (and their many product spinoffs): Pokemon, Digimon, DragonBall Z, Sailor Moon, Hamtaro and, most recently, Yu-Gi-Oh. It's enough to make Disney envious. 
 The spike-haired, doe-eyed girls and boys and sweetly pugilistic animal familiars of anime and manga are conventions of American childhood now. (And not just American childhood: the "Pokemon" cartoon series is broadcast in 65 countries around the world.) Japanese manufacturers rule the growing market for home video games, one that reaches into older demographics and rivals movie box-office sales in the United States. Hello Kitty and some of the other critters from the candy-toned dream world of Sanrio not only enjoy a terrific "awww" factor, they also have brand recognition to spare. (The Sanrio Web site lists 420 stores in California alone where its products are sold.) And while in the 1980's, Kitty products were customized for national markets -- research revealed that Americans didn't like snails as sidekicks and did like purple and pink -- Sanrio now markets the same products everywhere, having realized that Kitty's Japaneseness is a part of her appeal. 
 So has Japan become a cultural superpower -- an exporter of fashions, trends, gizmos, buzz and values -- just like the United States? That's what Douglas McGray argues in a lively article, "Japan's Gross National Cool," which appeared in the journal Foreign Policy earlier this year. Though a decade-long recession has robbed Japan of its economic power, the country has "far greater cultural influence now than it did in the 1980's," McGray observes, in areas ranging from "pop music to consumer electronics, architecture to fashion and food to art." And its accession to what McGray calls Pokemon hegemon suggests that economic and cultural prowess are not as straightforwardly linked as we might think. To be a cultural superpower, a country needs something more specific, it seems: a youth market with consumer clout. And Japan, like America, most definitely has one. 
Japan's "national cool," McGray argues, is a form of what the Harvard political scientist Joseph Nye calls "soft power" -- the nonmilitary, nonpolitical means by which a country can influence another country's values or it citizens' wants. And though, so far, Japan's media exports don't convey an obvious or coherent set of values -- akin to the capitalist individualism that American pop culture tends to package, for example -- they might, if Japan's culture-makers wake up to the consequences of their global reach. After all, Japanese pop culture already has certain aesthetic hallmarks: techno-obsession, warp-speed trend cycles and infatuation with childhood. Hello Kitty, hello world. Margaret Talbot

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Housing Growth Is Strongest in Eastern Part of State

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
WITH thousands of new jobs created in the casino, pharmaceutical and military industries over the last few years, eastern Connecticut's housing market has shown some of the strongest growth in the state.
 Thomas R. Switz, owner of Switz Real Estate Associates in Mystic and president of the Eastern Connecticut Association of Realtors, said median house prices rose 18 percent in the second quarter of this year compared with a year earlier and 14 percent in the third quarter. 
 "You're going to see that slow down, I'm sure, because the market can't sustain it -- wages aren't going up that fast," Mr. Switz said. "There's no way we can continue to run up at 14 to 18 percent." 
Connecticut's two easternmost counties led the state in percentage gains of new housing in the first half of the year as well, according to the state Department of Economic and Community Development. Towns in New London County reported issuing permits for 451 units of new housing in January through June, up 26 percent from 358 units in the first half of 2001. Windham County reported an increase of almost 30 percent, to 246 units from 190. Other counties had gains of 6 to 17 percent, except for Fairfield, where permits fell 22 percent.
William R. Sweeney, the city planner in Norwich in New London County, said his office had approved plans for 400 condominium units in the last 18 months, and it has almost that many more under consideration. "It's really happened in the last year and a half, that we've really seen the housing market explode," Mr. Sweeney said.
Mr. Sweeney said Norwich was trying to promote the development of higher-priced homes, because 18 percent of the city's housing stock is at a price level that qualifies under state guidelines as affordable for low-income families.
"We're basically carrying the burden of affordable housing for the region, and we need to be aggressive about building up the rest of the market," Mr. Sweeney said. "This sort of situation, where there is demand across the spectrum of the housing market, has made it possible for us to push the high end of the market."
Nicholas H. Mullane II, president of the Southeastern Connecticut Council of Governments, said 24,000 new jobs at the Foxwoods and Mohegan Sun casinos are driving the lower- to middle-income part of the market. Other parts of the tourism industry have also been adding workers. "Every rental apartment and room in the region is gone," Mr. Mullane said.
But there is also a shortage of housing at the upper end of the market, thanks to more than 3,000 jobs added by Pfizer in the last few years with construction of a new research campus in New London and expansion of its existing complex in Groton. In addition, Electric Boat, which builds submarines in Groton, has added several hundred new jobs in the last year.
THE council released a report this year that said in the five-year period ending in 2005, southern Connecticut will have to add as many as 5,100 housing units, about twice the rate of the previous decade. 
But Richard B. Erickson, a planner who completed a study of the southeastern Connecticut housing market for the council this year, said the growth in employment is not the only explanation for the sharp increase in demand.
"I identified five major factors that are affecting housing demand, housing supply and housing cost," he said. Single-person households, for instance, grew at a pace of 22 percent in the last decade, while the total population grew at just 1 percent. This trend has quickened demand for housing.
Restrictive local zoning policies, limited public sewers and water, a shortage of trades workers and a lack of available land for housing are other reasons that have crimped the housing supply, according to his 135-page analysis.
"I think the tendency is to view it simplistically, but if you really start digging into it, you realize this is a very complex situation," Mr. Erickson said. "There's not a single factor causing the housing shortage, and no one thing is going to come close to meeting the needs of housing in the region."
Mr. Erickson's study also asserted that despite the need, "public attitudes do not support the development of new housing," and several housing projects that have been proposed in recent months have faced significant opposition, including a complex of 172 one- and two-bedroom condominium and rental units on Route 82 in Norwich, planned by Cherenzia Excavation of Westerly, R.I. "If the area needs housing, people shouldn't think it all has to be in single-family subdivisions," said Thomas J. Ligouri, general counsel for Cherenzia. The company is finishing a 45-lot subdivision in Mystic and a 22-lot subdivision in Stonington.
"Because of the time and money it takes to meet all the municipal standards, the cost of the infrastructure and delays in the permitting process, only the big companies can afford to go through the process," Mr. Ligouri said. "The little builders are being squeezed right out of the market."
The Council of Governments has established a special commission on housing to examine the issue, headed by James P. Cronin, president of the Dime Savings Bank in Norwich, which has branches throughout the region and this year established a program it calls Champ, for Creating Housing -- Affordable Mortgage Program.
Under the program, experienced landlords can borrow up to 90 percent of the cost to purchase and renovate a multifamily unit, at 6 percent interest, a rate Mr. Cronin characterizes as particularly attractive. "It's so below market we don't expect to make any money on the program; we're only hoping not to lose money on it," he said. "The object here is to get these buildings rehabilitated and occupied and get the cash flow going to pay off their taxes and their mortgages."
The only restriction is that the landlord has to hold the property for at least 10 years. "We didn't want to have people flipping the properties, trying to get in and get out with a quick profit," Mr. Cronin said. "It's seen as a way to get landlords to invest in the community."
So far, the bank has backed renovations that provide 38 updated units of housing in different towns around the region, the largest being an eight-family apartment building in the Occum section of Norwich that is being rebuilt to house 12 families.
"It's been a neighborhood eyesore for a long period of time, and now it's going to be occupied by low- to moderate-income families," Mr. Cronin said. "We have a critical shortage of housing in the area, and as that became more and more evident -- and the government programs are doing as much as they can -- we decided it was time we as the private sector step forward and do something."
Norwich, because of its proximity to the two casinos, has been the area developers seem to have focused on early. 
Sofee T. Noblick, owner of Noblick Properties, which offers rental apartments, and president of the Norwich Property Owners Association, said about one-third of her tenants are casino employees, which is close to the average for the region. The increased demand, she said, has helped to combat urban blight.
"The rents have come up by at least a third in the last couple of years, which allows developers to put money into renovations," Mrs. Noblick said. A two-bedroom unit in the area will now bring anywhere from $700 to $1,200, she estimated, and a two-family house that might have sold for $50,000 two years ago will now bring $100,000.
BUT the small towns in the region say the new development in the area has been a mixed blessing. Peter F. Sielman, first selectman in Salem, a rural town northwest of New London, said Pfizer employees and their families now make up about 10 percent of the town's population. "They're great neighbors and get very involved in the town," Mr. Sielman said. "But if a family moves into town with two school-age children and the value of their house is less than $600,000, it costs the town more than we can collect in taxes."
Mr. Mullane, the president of the Council of Governments, said that because towns rely so heavily on the property tax to pay for schools, roads and any other services, towns would rather encourage commercial or industrial development, which pays more in taxes than it consumes in services.
"This area is creating some good argument in favor of tax reform," Mr. Mullane said. "What we call town roads, for instance, are really public roads, and especially those towns around the casino are seeing an enormous increase in traffic."
"I don't think we can focus on affordable or senior or assisted living or top-end housing -- we need to look at providing a broad range of housing," Mr. Mullane said. "It's going to take a bit more study to determine who had the best ideas, the best location, the best areas to build, the best housing grants to help out, and then broadly spread across the region. You don't want to have an unfair impact in any one community."
"We have to be looking at a wide variety of projects," Mr. Mullane said. "We can't close our mind to any kind of housing. All of them will contribute to a solution."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James P. Cronin of Dime Savings Bank at an apartment building in Norwich being rebuilt to house 12 families. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island; 
Officials Are Selling County and Town Real Estate

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE 

 BODY:
TWO of Long Island's largest governments are preparing to sell off some of their real estate and consolidate some offices. Nassau County is examining its extensive inventory of property as part of a wide-ranging effort to deal with a staggering budget deficit. And Brookhaven, a Suffolk County town that is larger in area than all of Nassau, is moving to centralize its operations and reduce operating costs in the process.
 The two governments have determined not only that they have more property than is ideal but also that in some cases offices are not situated in the most convenient places for many residents. This haphazardness reflects the explosive growth of Nassau since the middle of the 20th century and of Brookhaven over the past 25 years. 
 The efforts also reflect the fact that government officials seem to be paying more attention to real estate than they used to. "They are now thinking more like a private enterprise and trying to realize untapped value in their holdings and improve space efficiencies," said Martin L. Lomazow, senior managing director for Insignia/ESG, the real estate services company, which was hired as the exclusive broker for both the Brookhaven and Nassau consolidation projects. 
When Thomas R. Suozzi took office as Nassau County executive in January with a pressing need to deal with a projected budget deficit of $428 million over the next four years, he discovered there was no inventory of its properties.
"The problem resulted from the tremendous growth the county experienced over the past 50 years," Mr. Suozzi said. Nassau, which covers 298 square miles, grew from 400,000 people in 1940 to 1.3 million at present. "Explosive growth continued with government programs in the 1960's and 1970's, causing the county to either buy new, or rent, buildings." 
One of the first things he did was to hire the county's first real estate director, Sheldon L. Cohen, a lawyer who had spent 20 years as vice president of facilities and services at MetLife in Manhattan. 
In the first phase of the consolidation process, an inventory revealed that the county owned 2,500 properties, including 764 buildings that it occupies and 1,340 vacant parcels ranging from a one-square-foot piece of road to 138 acres of a 207-acre 4-H camp in eastern Suffolk, Mr. Cohen said. 
"We are now trying to get a handle on the properties, find out which ones are overlapping and determine which are surplus," said Richard Karson, a member of a 10-member Insignia team that is helping to develop Nassau's plan. 
Eventually, up to 20 buildings and dozens of small parcels may be sold and put back on the tax rolls, Mr. Suozzi said.
HE added that a six-member nonpartisan advisory panel had been set up to review the disposition of surplus properties and screen buyers to ensure there is no conflict of interest or political favoritism.
"Our goal is to take the county operations and consolidate them into five campuses: police, jail, courts, health and human services and the rest of the county offices," he explained. "The best example is health and human services, which has eight departments in different locations. We want them all in the same place so they can share administrative costs and be more accessible to the public."
Many agencies were found to be in rented buildings rather than in those that the county owned. Since January, $1 million has been saved by moving approximately 40 offices out of leased buildings into county-owned buildings, Mr. Cohen said. 
The first to move was the purchasing department, which had been paying an annual rent of $360,000 in a building it had used for 20 years surrounded by numerous county-owned buildings along Old Country Road in Mineola, the county seat. 
The financial advantages of moving from leased space to county-owned buildings may not, however, be a given. Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, said that in some cases there may be financial advantages in continuing to lease buildings. "They'll have to look closely into rental spaces, because with health or social services it could be an economic gain to lease," he said. "Those departments, if not located in a government building, would be reimbursed by the state for 50 percent of the cost to lease and maintain."
While plans for most properties are still being studied, Mr. Suozzi said, there are "some definites."
The jail in East Meadow and seven courthouses in Mineola will remain. Two are historic properties: the 134,400-square-foot 102-year-old original County Courthouse and the 73-year-old 273,600-square-foot current County Courthouse.
A two-story 18,393-square-foot Mineola building that houses the consumer affairs and human rights departments will be sold for approximately $2 million.
Two buildings and a 105-acre vacant parcel in Bethpage, which were part of the Grumman plant where aerospace products were manufactured, were deeded to the county by the United States Navy this week. A 19,560-square-foot building will be sold and a 660,000-square-foot building, where the lunar module was manufactured, is being considered for use by the public safety department.
The revenue from the sale of surplus county buildings will be applied to the renovation of existing buildings, Mr. Cohen said.
THE preliminary Nassau consolidation plan is expected to be released for public comment by the end of January. Once it is approved by the county executive, it will be sent to the County Legislature for a vote. 
"The obvious things have been done already," Mr. Suozzi said. "The big things will take off, we hope, by mid-2003."
Fifteen miles to the east, in the 347-year-old town of Brookhaven, the major focus of a consolidation plan is the $21 million purchase of a 221,000-square-foot office building -- currently owned by Allstate. Centralizing operations in that building is expected to save the town a quarter of a million dollars in operating expenses annually, according to John Jay LaValle, Brookhaven's supervisor. 
The three-story building is on 42 acres in Farmingville, centrally located in the 324-square-mile town, which has 448,519 residents. It is two miles north of a 150,000-square-foot complex of 10 buildings on 15 acres in Medford, which has housed most town offices for the past 15 years.
Thirteen tenants, including a delicatessen and a dentist, currently lease 38,000 square feet at the complex, paying annual rents ranging from $11.41 to $18.49 per square foot. 
THE tax receiver's office is in the village of Port Jefferson on the North Shore, and the town clerk is in a building that Brookhaven leases for $1 a year from the village of Patchogue on the South Shore. The Highway and Parks Department is in Coram. 
"Historically, the town offices had been in Patchogue," Dr. Koppelman said. "Forty years ago, it didn't matter. Most of the population was there. But in the last 25 years the population has moved to the center of the town and eastward."
In consolidating, the town will divest itself of three of the four properties and move all departments -- with the exception of the Coram facility -- to the Allstate building. 
The 9,000-square-foot Port Jefferson building will be sold, and the 12,000-square-foot Patchogue building will revert back to the village. 
Bidding for the Medford complex closed this week. Proceeds from the sale, which town officials hope will be about $10 million, will be used to pay off the remaining $9 million debt on the property. 
An adjacent one-and-a-half-acre vacant parcel, appraised at $295,000, may be sold separately, Mr. LaValle said. It was purchased last year for $235,000 before the town decided to sell the complex.
The three buildings cost $2.4 million a year to operate. It is estimated that the Allstate building will cost $2.1 million a year for debt service and operating costs. Under a five-year lease, Allstate will continue to occupy about 50,000 square feet on the second floor at an annual cost of $24.50 a square foot.
The 24-year-old building, which was renovated in the late 90's, is in "pristine condition," and because it already has high-technology wiring will bring the town "up to speed technologically," an undertaking that would have cost more than $1 million to accomplish in existing offices, Mr. LaValle said. The town hopes to close on the building by Jan. 1 and move in by August.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brookhaven is to buy a 221,000-square-foot building from Allstate and consolidate many town offices there. (Ed Betz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Struggling to Get Doctors' Attention

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
LAST month, about 15 executives and sales representatives from Vasomedicalin Westbury flew to Chicago for the annual American Heart Association meeting at McCormick Place. More than 25,000 cardiologists and other medical professionals attend the event each year, and Vaso, as the company is called, always makes it a point to be there.
 The company looks for every chance it can get to bring its product, a computerized blood pump, to the attention of cardiologists, hospital procurement officers and others who make or influence decisions about cardiac treatment. Vaso has sold about 600 pumps since the device was introduced in 1995 and believes that it can sell many more. 
 The catch is that in a market that considers high-tech synonymous with efficacy, Vaso manufactures a product that might be assembled for a high school science fair. Known as the Model TS-3 Enhanced External Counterpulsation System, the device pumps blood to the heart by inflating a series of cuffs strapped to the patient's legs. A computer monitors the heart, and while it pauses between beats, the cuffs pump blood upward, from the legs to the trunk. 
The concept of enhanced external counterpulsation is based on research initially done at Harvard half a century ago and advanced in China during the 1970's after American researchers lost interest. About 15 years ago, a small group of investors, most of them with backgrounds at midsize companies that made medical devices, acquired the patents to the technology and founded Vaso's predecessor. In 1995, the Food and Drug Administration approved the technology for the treatment of angina.
Last June, the F.D.A. approved enhanced external counterpulsation for the treatment of congestive heart failure, positioning Vaso to compete in a $40-billion-a-year market. In a much narrower field last year, the company recorded revenues of $27.5 million. 
"This development opens a vast and exciting market opportunity for us, years ahead of our most optimistic projections," said D. Michael Deignan, the company's president and chief executive at the time of the F.D.A. announcement. "We believe this noninvasive, cost-effective therapy will provoke a paradigm shift in the way cardiovascular diseases come to be treated."
Paradoxically, just two months later, on Aug. 31, the company ended its fiscal first quarter in a river of red ink, losing $4.2 million. The performance was disappointing, given the F.D.A. news and the company's growth in the previous year, when revenues doubled. On Oct. 22, Mr. Deignan resigned but continues as a consultant; he did not return a phone call seeking comment.
As for the "paradigm shift" he had so enthusiastically envisioned, that, too, has become a casualty, at least in the short term, of the realities of health-care economics and the intensity with which physicians guard their sources of revenue.
Photios T. Paulson, 63, a longtime Vaso director with years of experience running midsize medical companies, has become the company's new chief executive. "My priority as C.E.O. will be to build and execute a more effective business strategy, and consequently, our marketing efforts will be aimed toward selected market segments and decision makers through whom we can achieve faster market penetration. I am confident that the E.E.C.P. market will continue to grow." 
Although Vaso's pump has the potential of being prescribed for five million patients with heart disease in the United States, few of the nation's heart-care specialists have chosen to do so. The cost of the pump, about $230,000, is a fraction of many high-tech medical devices. Yet until Medicare and private insurers establish their reimbursement rates for treatment sessions with the pump for people with congestive heart failure, Vaso's market remains relatively narrow. 
Meanwhile, Vaso is paying for a $3.5 million study supervised by Dr. Arthur Feldman, the chairman of the department of medicine at Thomas Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia. The results of the study, if it bears out Vaso's expectations, will help put it on the radar of the country's medical decision makers. In this world, external counterpulsation is an anomaly. Investments commonly involve products that feature advances in technologies like laser surgery, angioplasty and implantation that have already been touted in professional journals and then discussed, before invited audiences, at educational seminars held at fine restaurants and resorts. 
In contrast, Vaso, which has cash reserves that are far from limitless, attempts to buttonhole prospects at events like the heart association gathering, then following up with calls asking for a few minutes when scheduling permits.
"We don't do the conferences in Bermuda" the way larger medical product companies and pharmaceutical manufacturers do, said Gregory D. Cash, who was named Vaso's president and chief operating officer on Oct. 31. "We try to talk with them one at a time, in their offices, when they can free a moment."
Vaso continues to deal with what it describes as an unwarranted suspicion among cardiologists that the company is their competitor.
"A large percentage of our customers are interventional cardiologists who are concerned that E.E.C.P. will cut into their angioplasty business," said Mr. Cash, 45. "I would say that more than a quarter of our customers perceived of us initially as a threat to their business."
Dr. Feldman, the principal investigator in the Vaso study, said patients with heart disease improve remarkably when they undergo external counterpulsation treatment. "I think it's an incredibly effective new therapy," he said. "We found that after 35 sessions these patients showed marked improvement," better than with conventional medications like diuretics and beta blockers. "I'm talking about people who could barely get up and walk across a room were now going out to play golf," he added.
The technology's very simplicity seems to work against it, Dr. Feldman said. "The cardiologist thinks, 'Put a catheter in,' so this noninvasive technology goes somewhat against their thought process," he said. "It's almost too simple. It's a shame that our current economic system of medicine is slowing down its utilization across the country."
Yet even Thomas Jefferson University Hospital, where Dr. Feldman practices, has not purchased the Vaso pump. "I've asked the hospital to buy one, but it is not in this year's budget," he said. "There are items of higher priority."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gregory D. Cash, left, and Photios T. Paulson with Vasomedical's pump. (Susan Farley for The New York Times) Graph tracks Vasomedical's share price since 2001 and a diagram shows how their new treatment for congestive heart failure works.

HEADLINE: A Tough Sell 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER 

DATELINE: CHERRY HILL 

 BODY:
RICH and Olga Montgomery were wheeling three grandsons through the Cherry Hill Mall, with three huge red shopping bags hanging off the back of a double stroller. Mr. Montgomery's job was to maintain order in the stroller, and Mrs. Montgomery's mission was to hunt down deals.
 "This year we are definitely looking for bargains," said the 65-year-old grandmother from nearby Mount Laurel. 
 The Montgomerys, who both retired five years ago -- she as a secretary in the Willingboro School District and he as an administrator for Dow Jones in South Brunswick -- are living on a fixed income. At the same time, they are facing grandchild inflation, up from 8 to 10 this year. 
Still, their biggest holiday Grinch this year is Wall Street.
"The stock market has been bad," said Mrs. Montgomery.
"And how," the 68-year-old Mr. Montgomery piped in.
The annual holiday buying binge is in full swing, with the traditional rituals of long checkout lines and crowded parking lots. But an unsettled economy, exaggerated in New Jersey because of the loss of thousands of jobs on Wall Street and in the telecommunications industry, has made holiday shoppers cautious this year. Unemployment is at uncomfortable levels -- 5.5. percent in October in New Jersey as against 4.7 percent last year and 3.7 percent in 2000 -- and the lingering fear of terrorism and a possible war with Iraq seem to have taken the bounce out of the step of many shoppers.
Yet opinions on how this shopping season is shaping up depends on who is doing the talking -- mall operators with their best holiday smiles or forecasters talking economics, otherwise known as the dismal science.
"Customers are definitely shopping the sales," said Billie Scott, a spokeswoman for Simon Property Group Inc. of Indianapolis, which operates four major malls in the state.
Indeed, with the nation's second-highest median income -- $52,000 compared with $42,000 for the United States as a whole -- New Jersey will have a holiday season that will not be quite as bleak as a tale told by Dickens.
"I don't think it's going to be a spectacular holiday season, but it should be a solid one," said Gus Faucher, who specializes in New Jersey at Economy.com, an economic forecasting company in Pennsylvania.
Elaborating a bit, Mr. Faucher said: "It's not going to be like it was in the late 1990's or 2000. On the other hand, the state isn't in recession. Things should be O.K., but not fantastic."
Retailers who were bracing for slow sales have been pleasantly surprised, said Richard Santoro, assistant vice president of the New Jersey Retail Merchants Association.
"Starting with Black Friday, sales were very encouraging, and we're hoping to continue that success as the season draws closer," said Mr. Santoro. "Of course, there are six less shopping days this year and concerns about the Middle East are on consumers' minds. But up to this point it seems retailers are at, or above, their projections."
For his part, Mr. Faucher said he is forecasting retail sales -- excluding automobiles -- to rise 4 to 5 percent in the fourth quarter in New Jersey.
Yet according to Ira Kalish, chief economist of Retail Forward, a consulting firm in Columbus, Ohio, those figures could lag behind the rest of the nation.
"I think New Jersey is going to have a worse Christmas than the rest of the country," he said. "The New York metropolitan area is still feeling the effects of Sept. 11, and more so the decline in stock prices that affect employment and income."
On New Jersey's main streets, merchants are also seeing hesitancy -- the result of an economy in which consumers have less confidence than they did six months ago.
"It's going slowly," said Marceline Lotman, owner of Her Own Place in Moorestown, which has been selling antiques and estate jewelry since 1979.
Ms. Lotman noted, "There are a lot of jobs that have been lost, and people are really feeling that."
Whether the season will be successful or lackluster, no one is immune to the lure of a bargain -- be it Florsheim or Fendi.
"Even though we are an upscale property, I think that this year consumers are looking for discounts," said Mike McAvinue, general manger of the Mall at Short Hills.
Mr. McAvinue said the Friday after Thanksgiving, the traditional kickoff to the holiday shopping season, went surprisingly well, with the parking decks that surround the sprawling mall full by noon. In most years, he said, that did not happen by 1 or 2 p.m. And in most holiday seasons, Hanukkah does not fall so early, which this year was the day after Thanksgiving -- known to retailers as Black Friday because the lucrative holiday season puts them in the black.
"It was a great weekend overall," said Mr. McAvinue. "The consumer seemed to be upbeat and optimistic. It seemed like they were in a great mood." Still, he cautioned, "It's only the first inning."
If this season has boon to any group, it has been the personnel managers. With the unemployment rate in New Jersey higher than usual, merchants have had a better selection of potential employees, though they have been cautious about adding too much staff in case sales sag.
Mr. McAvinue said that when stores at the Short Hills mall advertised for positions last year they received two to three applicants for each job. This year, he said, they have typically had 10.
Retail stores comprise the state's second-largest employer behind services, making up 16 percent of total employment, compared with 18 percent nationally.
"In terms of the number they are hiring compared to last year it's about the same," Mr. McAvinue said. "But the quality of the candidate we've been hiring has been very good. Given the job market, there's a better pool of employees out there."
On an overall employment base of more than 4 million, New Jersey added 10,000 jobs in October, and of that 1,000 were in the retail sector. Hardware stores added 700 workers and food stores an additional 600. But general merchandisers and apparel stores cut employment by 400 jobs each.
In the past, said Mr. Faucher of Economy.com, fourth-quarter retail employment usually went up by one to two percentage points. In the fourth quarter of 2001, for instance, retail employment figures in New Jersey increased by 7,000. In 2000 it was up 9,000.
Yet for all the seasonal help, one question is repeated by shoppers almost as much as "It's a Wonderful Life" is shown on television: what's taking so long in the checkout line?
On a slow day at the Cherry Hill Mall Devonia Ramseur pointed to a line at the Gap that was nearly a dozen people deep.
"They know it's Christmas," Mrs. Ramseur complained. "They never have enough people. Every time I make it up to pay there are two registers but one is always empty."
Since July, Seventy McNee has been working part-time for Macy's in Cherry Hill at the fragrance counter. Ms. McNee, a full-time student, wanted to give notice that she planned to leave her job a month ago, but the store managers persuaded her stay through the holidays -- even giving her a bonus for helping them to recruit her husband for a security position for a month.
"I think it is always hard to get employees at the holidays," she said. "They were definitely begging me to stay."
From her vantage point behind the counter, Mrs. McNee said she, too, had seen customers clutching their wallets a bit tighter this season.
"They definitely want the smaller bottle or the one that comes in a gift set," she said. One customer, she said, stood at her counter for about 10 minutes weighing whether to spend $18.50 or $35 on one present. 
"Finally she want with the $35 one," said Mrs. McNee, "but she really thought about it."
Across the counter, one shopper, Alice Tribbett, of Marlton, said she had cut back on the number of people on her gift list.
"I just don't want to spend the money," Ms. Tribbett said. "That's the bottom line."
Tight-fisted shoppers aside, this year's abbreviated shopping season -- created not only by the early Hanukkah but by a relatively late Thanksgiving -- has haunted retailers. Then came a snowstorm, closing schools and making travel difficult.
Still, Elizabeth Platt, marketing director for the Rockaway Town Square in Morris County, chose to see the snow as a potential marketing device.
"It might create more of a sense of urgency," said Ms. Platt. "Snow creates more of that wintry holiday atmosphere and puts shoppers more in the spirit -- after the roads are clear."
But once the roads are cleared, the frustration can set in, fueled by long lines and the anticipation of unappreciated presents. To counter that weariness, shoppers try to stay focused and move quickly.
Mr. McAvineu from the Mall at Short Hills said he had noticed more people referring to their lists to keep them on track, and families using walkie-talkies to help speed the process.
He said he helped a customer with nine shopping bags back to her car on the day after Thanksgiving.
"I asked her, 'How did you do all this so fast?' " said McAvinue. "She said she used the Internet and catalogs to prepare her list of what she wanted, but she wanted to avoid the shipping charges and still be able to feel and touch what she was buying."
Of course, holiday time means a proliferation of promotions to entice the weary and the wary. Dogs and children are easy targets. Take the Mall at Short Hills, which held what it billed as its first Santa Paws event in which people brought their pets to be photographed with Santa Claus. More than 300 dogs -- but only a few cats -- were brought in over two nights.
But promotions and gimmicks can only go so far. The more pragmatic shoppers are turning to gift certificates and the Internet this year. During the week including Thanksgiving, shoppers spent $1.5 billion on the Internet, up 41 percent over the same period last year, according to ComScore Networks of Reston, Va.
In New Jersey, that has been a bonus for the State Museum in Trenton, which has been offering selected merchandise from its shop over the Internet for three years.
The museum sells "Trenton Makes the World Takes" T-shirts as well as caps and sweatshirts that spell out New Jersey in an elegant script; there is a watch with the state quarter as its face, and a paperweight with the Great Seal of New Jersey.
"Business has been growing gradually," said Becky Morrisson, manager of the museum shop. "It has been exciting for us. We're testing the waters and seeing how many people have an interest in New Jersey."
