HEADLINE: The Nation: Politics of the Economy; 
The Players Are in Place. The Policies Await.

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH'S replacement of his top economic aides last week showed how seriously he takes the threat that a weak economy poses to his political future. But that concern so far has not extended to reconsidering his core economic policies. Unemployment is rising and growth worldwide appears to have stalled, but almost no one expects the White House to propose major short-term tax cuts or spending to revive the economy.
 Instead, the administration's most important proposal remains a package of long-term tax cuts, directed mainly at the wealthy, a remedy that many mainstream economists say is bafflingly out of step with the problems the economy faces right now. 
 Yet the White House's strategy may be smarter and more effective than the economists give it credit for. To begin with, the president's new team -- John W. Snow as Treasury secretary, Stephen Friedman as chairman of the National Economic Council and William H. Donaldson as Securities and Exchange Commission chairman -- is much stronger than its predecessor, and will be perceived as such, economists and Wall Street strategists said.
"You have a very good combination of market savvy and also industrial experience, and a level of talent that is equal to any administration in the last couple of decades," said Jeffrey Garten, dean of the Yale School of Management and an under secretary of the Commerce Department in the Clinton administration. 
The real question, then, is not about the players but about the policies. With the risk of another recession rising, the administration's main response thus far has been to propose making permanent supposedly temporary tax cuts that were passed last year, and possibly accelerating them.
Those cuts, scheduled to take effect by 2010, are mainly directed at the highest-income Americans. Most mainstream economists say that temporary tax cuts directed at low- and moderate-wage earners or aid to local governments to allow them to avoid raising taxes next year would be much better short-term alternatives.
"The soft patch is principally a function of war jitters," said Richard DeKaser, chief economist at National City Bank in Cleveland and a self-described political independent. "To alleviate that problem, you want to do something that is short term in nature. You don't want to do something that is going to be with us for many years."
Mr. DeKaser said the measures he and many other economists favor include encouraging business investment by allowing companies to take bigger tax write-offs on new equipment, a measure business supports, and extending unemployment insurance for laid-off workers, "who are overwhelmingly inclined to spend every dollar they have."
On the other hand, the promise of tax cuts several years away will do little to increase business investment in 2003 and nothing at all to encourage consumer spending. 
SO why is the White House sticking to its long-term policy? 
It is not necessarily because the Bush administration is in love with supply-side economics -- the notion that permanent reductions in tax rates, especially the higher rates paid by the wealthy, are a solution to every economic problem and pay for themselves by generating more tax revenues through increased growth.
In any case, none of Mr. Bush's new hires are known as supply-siders. "Bush has plucked apparently every surviving member of the Ford administration for his inner circle, ignoring the Reagan guys, who are ideologically committed to the supply side," said James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. "He is giving at least lip service to supply-side ideas but surrounding himself with people who disagree with them."
A better explanation for the administration's policies, economic and political analysts say, is that far from being ill conceived, they are intended to further political as well as economic goals.
Stephen Moore, president of the Club for Growth, a political action committee that supports candidates who favor lower taxes, noted that tax cuts are intended to spur growth, but also to control the size of government by depriving it of the money needed to create new programs. "Tax cuts create resource constraints on politicians," he said. "And that is a good thing." 
So even if the administration didn't believe tax cuts pay for themselves with stronger growth, it might not care that they will create larger deficits, because deficits keep government from spending more.
THE strategy is a risky one, said Jared Bernstein, a senior economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research group, because without a strong stimulus package, the economy might remain weak in 2003 and even into 2004. "They're throwing the dice a bit here," he said.
But even if the lack of short-term stimulus proves bad for the economy, it could still work politically, said Bill Allison of the non-partisan Center for Public Integrity. 
Lowering taxes on the wealthy and repealing the estate tax are both issues dear to the president's conservative base. And the White House has probably calculated that low- and middle-income voters will give the president credit for whatever tax rebates or cuts they receive next year, even if the Democrats propose them. That happened in 2001, when Democrats insisted that the president's tax cut plan include a $300 rebate for almost every taxpayer.
"That was a Democratic Party idea, and look who got credit for it," Mr. Allison said. "By and large, it was Bush." 
So the White House may expect, and even want, the tax package Congress passes next year to include a temporary payroll tax holiday or extension of unemployment insurance. But it will force the Democrats to ask for those, and extract concessions on other tax cuts as its price.
So far, the strategy seems to have worked, given that opinion polls give Mr. Bush more credit than the Democrats for guiding the economy. "You just have to look at the approval numbers," Mr. Allison said.

HEADLINE: The World; 
If the Scuds Were Going to Iraq

BYLINE:  By THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH the United States tries mightily to discourage the trade of high-tech weaponry into unstable regions, the Bush administration had little practical choice last week but to let a shipment of Scud missiles sail on to Yemen from North Korea.
 The initial seizure of the freighter and its cargo was certainly legal: the vessel was flying no flag and its markings were obscured by paint, rendering it a stateless, lawless vessel not unlike a pirate ship. 
 But this commercial transaction for armament between two nations was not barred by any treaty either had signed, and President Bush ordered the ship set free. 
It would have been different had the ultimate buyer proved to be, say, Iraq, or a stateless terrorist network.
If Baghdad was in on the deal, the missiles could have been confiscated under United Nations sanctions on arms sales to Iraq. Or Mr. Bush could have said that Iraq was in breach of United Nations resolutions and that he had grounds for war.
The missiles could also have been seized forever if the buyer was an organization that wasn't a state -- Al Qaeda, for example.
Even with last week's sale, some international lawyers say paperwork could have been thrown at the problem in an attempt to tie up the ship and its cargo for years. Because it flew no flag, the vessel might have been held until its last legal owner laid claim. 
That owner might have given permission to destroy the cargo. Or the cargo might have been locked up, having been shipped under false manifest.
Any idea of trying those tactics, though, fell before the dictates of diplomacy and the logic of maintaining an alliance.
Simply put, Yemen was deemed too valuable a partner in the campaign to eradicate terrorism.
In fact, it was the hunt for Al Qaeda that made the seizure possible. During the war in Afghanistan, the United States organized patrols in and near the Arabian Sea to stop terrorists trying to flee for lawless regions in the Horn of Africa. About 10 countries volunteered vessels.
Even with the dispiriting outcome, last week's maritime seizure had one redeeming effect, administration officials said.
It made it clear, they said, that America can detect clandestine arms shipments and, with its allies, stop them at sea.

HEADLINE: The World; 
Three Targets, Three Strategies

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH'S diplomatic strategy for December was hardly a mystery: Focus attention on a unique threat posed by Iraq, one that could be neutralized only by disarming the country and deposing Saddam Hussein.
 But last week the two other members of the "axis of evil," North Korea and Iran, suddenly created nuclear-sized distractions, raising a question the White House wants to glide past: Is the threat from Iraq the most imminent threat to America and the world? 
 In quick succession, the United States failed to block a shipment of North Korean missiles to Yemen, North Korea said it was resuming production of weapons-grade plutonium, and satellite photographs showed huge progress in Iran's bomb program. 
"What the president may have just discovered," said Gary Milhollin, the director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, "is that Iraq is actually the least complicated of the three cases. And his team is going to earn its pay in the next few months figuring out the other two." 
North Korea may not have Iraq's malicious intent, but it owns at least two nuclear weapons, the means to deliver them, and a huge conventional force facing South Korea, Japan and American troops in Asia. 
But as a senior American official put it last month: "We are taking on Iraq because we can, without doing much damage elsewhere. We are tripping over ourselves on North Korea because there is no military option we can live with, and no diplomatic option that the White House likes."
In fact, there's been a different strategy for each point on the axis. For Iraq, it's confrontation. For Iran, it's hands off. 
"If we get involved, overtly or covertly" in Iran's internal struggles between democratic reformists and hard-liners, a senior aide to Mr. Bush said, "we'll only be hurting our own interests."
In North Korea, the administration has followed a boa-constrictor strategy ever since North Korea admitted in October that it has secretly been working to develop a weapon from highly enriched uranium. Last month, the administration organized its allies to put a slow squeeze on the North Korean economy by cutting off the oil that was supposed to compensate for an agreement to stay away from nuclear power.
Unlike Iraq, argues Condoleezza Rice, the president's national security adviser, North Korea has no oil revenue, making it vulnerable to economic pressure. And unlike Iran, she notes, it has no indigenous democracy movement to encourage.
"This time around, the economic carrot and stick will be much more effective," said Han Sung Joo, a former South Korean foreign minister. "The North is more dependent on us than it was during the last nuclear crisis," in 1994.
That contention may one day prove true, but so far North Korea has been defiant. On Thursday, it said it was switching on the nuclear reactor that was shut down under the 1994 agreement, which can produce enough plutonium to make a few nuclear weapons a year. The White House described the North Korean decision as "regrettable."
The White House has been even more restrained in how it describes allies that help feed North Korea's nuclear habit.
When American spy satellites detected a Pakistani plane picking up North Korean missiles in July, there was no public criticism, even though the C.I.A. has said North Korea's missile sales pay for its nuclear program. "It's another piece of evidence," one American diplomat said, "that Pakistan may be our biggest problem."
When the same satellites warned that a North Korean freighter loaded with hidden Scud missiles was headed for the Middle East, the United States arranged for Spain to stop the ship last week. The ship was turned over to American forces -- until it turned out that the buyer was Yemen, a new American ally. The Yemenis called Vice President Dick Cheney and the cargo was delivered.
The next day, commercial satellite photographs of Iran's newest nuclear sites were broadcast around the world. Again the White House was silent. 
So what happened to Mr. Bush's declaration that when it comes to fighting terror, and keeping the world's worst weapons out of the hands of the world's worst dictators, nations are "with us or against us"?
It is one of those phrases, administration officials say, that remain a fine statement of national goals. "The execution, however," one senior official concedes, "is a little bit trickier."

HEADLINE: Bush Calls for an Extension Of Unemployment Benefits 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 

 BODY:
President Bush called on Congress today to act immediately when it convenes next month to reinstate unemployment benefits for 750,000 people whose assistance will run out three days after Christmas.
 Mr. Bush said the benefits should be paid retroactively to Dec. 28 once they are restored. He otherwise offered few specifics of the legislation he wants passed by Congress, where his party will be in control of the Senate and the House starting in January. 
 Unemployed workers "need our assistance in these difficult times, and we cannot let them down," Mr. Bush said in his weekly radio address.
"I have shared these concerns with the leaders of the House and the Senate, and they understand the need for early action," he said. "When our legislators return to the Capitol, I ask them to make the extension of unemployment benefits a first order of business. And the benefits they approve should be retroactive, so that people who lose their benefits this month will be paid in full."
States typically provide laid-off workers with 26 weeks of unemployment benefits, and the federal government has routinely extended the benefits in hard periods for the economy. This year, Congress authorized a 13-week extension, but that authorization runs out on Dec. 28.
Mr. Bush noted that the House and the Senate had passed differing versions of legislation that would have extended the benefits again, but had not agreed on a compromise before adjourning last month. He did not mention that Democrats criticized him last month, saying he had not pressed Republican leaders aggressively enough to make a deal, or that they stepped up the pressure on him in the past week to act immediately.
On Friday, Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee said they would introduce a bill on the first day Congress was back in session that would provide an additional 26 weeks of coverage to laid-off workers. 
"President Bush has said he is a compassionate conservative, but apparently that compassion does not extend to the unemployed," said Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the senior Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee. "He stood silent on the sidelines as Republicans in the House blocked an extension of unemployment benefits to millions of laid-off workers. We will introduce legislation to correct this inequity, and we hope he supports it this time."
The unemployment rate last month stood at 6 percent, equaling its highest rate since mid-1994. The figure represents 8.5 million people who do not have jobs but are looking for work. With the the stock market also in the doldrums, the White House has become increasingly concerned about the political implications for Mr. Bush as he heads toward his re-election race in 2004. 
In his radio address, Mr. Bush noted that he brought in a new economic team this week and said there were encouraging signs about the economy, including low inflation and interest rates. 
Critics of Mr. Bush's suggested that he would not push for legislation to assist unemployed workers whose original round of benefits would run out in coming months, or those who had already exhausted the first extension.
"Today's announcement is way too little, way too late," said Maurice Emsellem of the National Employment Law Project, a liberal advocacy group. "It's absolutely no comfort to the one million unemployed workers who already ran out of their extended benefits and the 90,000 each week who will be entitled to no federal help starting January 1st."
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, issued a statement saying the president "must now urge the House Republican leadership to accept the bipartisan compromise" worked out in the Senate last month that would have extended benefits for all unemployed workers for 13 more weeks.

HEADLINE: U.S. Raises Abortion Issue At Conference On Families 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 

 BODY:
Taking its fight against abortion overseas, the Bush administration opened a sharp debate over a landmark family-planning agreement during a United Nations conference this week, angering several of its allies, European and Asian diplomats said today.
 The skirmish has been taking place at a United Nations regional family-planning conference in Bangkok, where the United States has threatened to withdraw its support for a 1994 family-planning agreement reached in Cairo that called for bringing population growth under control by improving the legal rights and economic status of women, as well as broadly expanding access to health care. 
 Administration officials contend that some phrases in the Cairo agreement -- including "reproductive health services" and "reproductive rights" -- can be construed as promoting abortion. The Bush administration has also called for inserting language that promotes "natural" family-planning methods, officials said. 
But an array of Asian and European diplomats attending the conference, as well as representatives of nonprofit organizations observing the event, asserted on Friday that the United States delegation was virtually isolated in its position. These observers said the administration was opposed by the majority of the approximately 30 nations represented at the conference, including India, Indonesia, China and Pakistan.
They also argued that the American delegation's refusal to budge from its demands had stalemated the conference and made discussion of other pressing issues, like H.I.V. and AIDS prevention, impossible. 
"People hoped to discuss very practical, service oriented things: how to develop services to deal with sexually transmitted infections, H.I.V. and AIDS, how to do sex education," an Asian diplomat said. "People's frustration was that we're not able to discuss what we really want to discuss, because the U.S. insists on renegotiating key Cairo concepts which we are not willing to do."
Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a New York Democrat who supports abortion rights and who sent an observer to the conference, said, "This is another example of the Bush Administration versus the world that, regrettably, will be at the expense of women."
But a State Department official asserted that "some participants in the conference are seeking to force the United States to agree to language supporting abortion."
"Our goals are to focus on poverty, health and education, respect for women and the family as the fundamental unit of society," the official said. "We seek an outcome that does not support or promote abortion."
The fight in Bangkok comes at a time when the Bush administration has been trying to win international support for its Iraq policies and to dispel the perception that it is increasingly acting on its own. Some delegates argued that the dispute was undermining both efforts.
Those critics also asserted that the Bush White House, like the Reagan White House before it, was carrying the abortion fight overseas mainly to bolster its support among Catholic and fundamentalist Christian voters.
The critics also pointed to the presence of a former adviser to the Vatican, John Klink, on the United States delegation in Bangkok and at previous family-planning conferences. A State Department official said Mr. Klink was serving in a voluntary capacity at the behest of the White House. 
"This is purely about domestic politics," said Adrienne Germain, president of the International Women's Health Coalition.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSIT SHOWDOWN: AN ASSESSMENT; 
Workers Weigh the Cost of a Strike Against Years of Feeling Mistreated

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
It may seem irrational on many levels that the transit workers' union would even consider going on strike tomorrow when its leaders and the rank and file face an injunction, immense fines, possible jail sentences and the public's wrath.
 But a subtle calculus explains why, despite possibly stratospheric costs, the city's 34,000 subway and bus workers might still walk out: Proud but feeling largely unappreciated, they may prefer to stand up and show they will not be pushed around rather than accept a contract they feel continues a pattern of psychological and financial neglect. 
 And if they end up getting fined for striking, at least they can tell their children and grandchildren -- as did many transit workers who walked out in 1966 and 1980 -- that they fought the good fight.
Indeed, many of today's transit workers say that a major factor propelling them toward a strike is psychological -- the feeling that neither Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg nor Gov. George E. Pataki nor the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has treated them with the respect they deserve. 
They feel Mr. Bloomberg slighted them by not attending funeral services for two subway workers who died in separate on-the-job accidents last month. They feel snubbed because the mayor and the governor have rebuffed their requests to come to the bargaining table and to pressure the authority to speed up what the union calls a glacial negotiating pace.
They are angry that they are being called unpatriotic and callous because Mr. Pataki has said a strike would be an act of disloyalty and Mr. Bloomberg has warned that New Yorkers would die in a strike because the streets would be so clogged that emergency vehicles could not get through. 
Robert W. Snyder, a Rutgers University professor who has written a book on the history of the Transport Workers Union, predicted that the members of Local 100 just might shut down the nation's largest transit system because they feel they have been treated shabbily, before and during the current contract talks.
"Respect is in the middle of it," he said. "You have to show people enough respect that they can walk away from the bargaining table with their heads up."
Professor Snyder said that the mind-set of many transit workers mirrored that of miners, another group of workers who face many dangers on the job. Both groups have developed an unusual sense of solidarity as well as a macho defiance, and they do not take indignities lightly.
The transit workers say they were especially insulted the day after the first subway worker died last month when Mayor Bloomberg voiced little sympathy but sternly warned of severe penalties if the union carried out its then-vague strike threat.
Many workers and their union leaders say the authority has trifled with them because 48 hours before tomorrow's 12:01 a.m. contract deadline, management continued to call for a wage freeze in the first year, offered raises in the second or third years only with productivity increases, and demanded givebacks that would cost each worker about $1,500 a year.
The M.T.A.'s chief negotiator, Gary Dellaverson, asserted that the authority's insistence on a wage freeze and concessions had nothing to do with a lack of respect but was caused by the authority's deficit of more than $2 billion. He said that prevents the authority from even coming close to offering the union the 6 percent annual wage increase it is seeking for three years. 
"The union has to recognize the economic realities that we face," Mr. Dellaverson said. 
City officials said Mr. Bloomberg was not slighting or snubbing the transit workers, but just standing up to a union that has threatened to break the law and the authority's budget. 
Workers have also raised racial concerns as a dynamic in the contract dispute. Two-thirds of the union's membership are minorities, with a heavy representation of African-Americans and Caribbean immigrants. 
"The racial subtext to this confrontation should not be ignored," Professor Snyder said. "This is a union of predominantly people of color -- their leader is a black man who immigrated from Trinidad -- and they feel they face a municipal power structure that is overwhelmingly white."
Labor historians say there are parallels to 1966, when Mike Quill, the union's president and an immigrant from Ireland, defied Mayor John V. Lindsay and led a 12-day transit strike. At the time, the union was largely Irish and many members, including Mr. Quill, felt an ethnic resentment from the patrician mayor who personified a white Anglo-Saxon Protestant establishment.
When transit workers see their union offered a wage freeze not long after three municipal unions with white majorities -- the teachers, police and firefighters -- received double-digit raises, some see racial injustice at work.
M.T.A. officials deny that race is a factor in the discrepancy, pointing out that the three earlier contracts resulted from a previous round of negotiations that took place when there were budget surpluses. They also say that the transit workers received a double-digit raise in that round. These officials note that the transit union is the first to go to the bargaining table in a new wave of negotiations, which are taking place against a stark backdrop of large deficits.
Many transit workers complain that they earn less than their counterparts at Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road, both of which have a far lower proportion of minority workers. Authority officials acknowledge the transit workers' lower salaries, but say they are offset by higher pensions.
Even the proudest Local 100 worker will have to weigh the threat of high fines in deciding whether to walk out. The state's Taylor Law calls for a penalty of two days' pay for each day of a strike. If the union were to strike for 11 days, as it did in 1980, workers would lose 22 days' pay or nearly 10 percent of their annual wages. 
With this in mind, one adviser to the union predicted that if there was a strike, it might last only a day or two, which would allow workers to demonstrate their unhappiness without incurring a huge financial cost. 
Many labor relations experts predict that the transit workers will not strike if the authority makes a contract offer that Roger Toussaint, the local's president, is convinced shows his members real respect, perhaps by overhauling a disciplinary system that they feel results in far too many citations for petty offenses.
"The final offer has to show a willingness, within the current bad economic climate, to recognize the contribution these workers make to keeping the city going and to recognize it with a pay increase," said Joshua Freeman, a labor historian at Queens College. "If the offer just treats them as if they were troublemakers and problems for the city, that might cause them to walk."

HEADLINE: Chavez Rejects Call by U.S. for Early Vote in Venezuela 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 14 

 BODY:
President Hugo Chavez's government, whipsawed by a 13-day strike that is debilitating the economy, has rejected a Bush administration call for early elections to resolve the political turmoil in this oil-rich nation.
 Government officials said today that an early election, as demanded by the opposition, would be in violation of the country's Constitution, which permits a binding referendum on the president's rule no earlier than August. 
 "I'm sure President Bush is not telling the world that Venezuelans must violate the Constitution," Mr. Chavez told four American reporters in an interview late tonight. "Here, there is no power that can convoke an early election, so I have asked Washington to review our Constitution."
Mr. Chavez's comments came as Thomas Shannon, a special State Department envoy, met with government officials and opposition leaders to discuss possible solutions to a growing crisis that is of deep concern to the Bush administration.
"We came to the conclusion that the situation was sufficiently grave enough that it was important that the Venezuelans understood that we thought moving toward early elections was the best way to resolve this," Mr. Shannon, deputy assistant secretary for Western Hemisphere affairs, said this morning as he prepared to return to Washington.
Though Foreign Minister Roy Chaderton explained that he "took into account the ideas and observations" offered by Mr. Shannon, the Chavez administration clearly did not agree with the White House proposal.
"We would have preferred the White House's position be presented in another manner," he said in an interview this morning.
The administration's proposal for "the holding of early elections" was widely viewed here as an endorsement of the opposition's position. Mr. Chavez, though, has said his foes should wait until August for a referendum on his rule, which could revoke his presidency, or the next presidential election, set for 2006.
Mr. Chaderton said he was worried about the precedent that early elections would set, since opposition leaders often point to Mr. Chavez's fall in popularity and governing style in arguing for his removal.
"The problem is, are they going to do elections every time the opposition decides it wants to take power?" Mr. Chaderton said.
He did not rule out the possibility that the government would discuss a path toward early elections, but he said an early election could only happen if the Constitution were amended, the ferociously anti-Chavez news media demonstrated restraint and a new less-partisan electoral board were formed.
His comments underscored the difficult nature of the talks, in which the government views the opposition as coup plotters and the government's foes see Mr. Chavez as a despot taking Venezuela to economic ruin. As increasingly tense protests take place in the street and the economy founders, the two sides remain at an impasse in negotiations being mediated by Cesar Gaviria, general secretary of the Organization of American States.
Indeed, Mr. Chaderton said he believed that while the opposition talks about elections, it was really interested in simply toppling Mr. Chavez. "There is a conspiracy set up to overthrow the government," the foreign minister said.
The Bush administration, though, concluded that Mr. Chavez should convene an early election because the country was reaching the point where the deadlock between the government and its opponents could set off violence.
Mr. Shannon said the United States strongly supports a negotiated solution brokered by Mr. Gaviria, but stressed that it should happen quickly because of the volatile nature of the situation here.
"The level of confrontation could very easily slip beyond the grasp of Venezuela's institutions and its political leadership," Mr. Shannon said.
The Bush administration, worried about Venezuelan oil supplies, appeared to be taking its most forceful stand on the crisis here since April, when the White House tacitly supported the brief removal of Mr. Chavez from office in the wake of a national strike. 
An American official involved in shaping Venezuela policy justified the new position, saying that it was "not sufficient for the government to sit on institutional legitimacy when the country is at risk."
The American call, though, has raised concerns that it might do more harm than good, hurting Washington's standing in Caracas while setting a potentially perilous precedent in other Latin American countries with weak governments and institutions.
"I think the U.S. could be making a bit of the same mistake they made in April, getting more involved than they have to or going further than they have to in expressing their opinions," said Janet Kelly, a political analyst here. "Talking about whether the Constitution is a straitjacket strikes me as untoward."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators flooded an expressway in Caracas, Venezuela, yesterday, demanding the resignation of President Hugo Chavez after he had dismissed a call for early elections. (Lynsey Addario/Corbis Saba, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Galleria to Be Sold and Spruced 

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THE Mills Corporation of Arlington, Va., announced on Tuesday that it will acquire the Galleria at White Plains. The company, a real estate investment trust that owns, develops, leases, manages and markets properties, plans to add a fifth floor, a single-screen movie theater, at least one upscale restaurant and a PBS Kids' play area, among other things, to the 22-year-old, 885,000-square-foot Galleria. 
 The company is buying the White Plains property and four others (Broward Mall in Fort Lauderdale; Dover Mall and Dover Commons in Dover, Del., Northpark Mall in Jackson, Miss., and The Esplanade in New Orleans) from Cadillac Fairview Corporation of Toronto and plans to close on the deal by the end of January. It is also buying the 637,000-square-foot Riverside Square mall in Hackensack, N.J. The total acquisition price of all the properties is $621 million, the company said. 
 David Douglass, a spokesman for Mills, said there were no separate figures for the Galleria's purchase price. Sam Bornstein, a spokesman for Cadillac Fairview, said a number of companies expressed interest in buying the five properties, but he would not say why his company, which is based in Toronto, was selling -- only that it "has been rebalancing its portfolio for about 18 months." 
Mr. Douglass said plans for the Galleria included an effort to make it a "more fun place to visit." Mills, a publicly traded company, trademarked the term Shoppertainment, and combines retail and entertainment aspects of shopping. Mills has gone into partnership with a number of brands including ESPN, Crayola and Gibson Guitar to build retail-entertainment attractions. 
Mills's Lakewood, Colo., mall, for example, has an ESPN X-Games Skatepark, a concept developed by Mills and ESPN; its Discover Mills near Atlanta features a Bass Pro Shops Outdoor World, where customers can practice fly fishing. Other centers have ice-skating rinks and miniature NASCAR race tracks. 
At the Galleria, which has 130 tenants, Mills plans to add a PBS Kids area and cluster retail outlets specializing in children's items like clothing and toys nearby. Seven months ago, the Public Broadcasting Service and Mills announced a marketing alliance to develop the children's activity areas inside new and existing Mills properties.
The learn-and-play areas feature educational activities for parents and children, presented in conjunction with local public television stations. The areas have jungle gyms, live events, book nooks, computer kiosks and community boards with information on PBS Kids programming and community events. 
The new owners also plan to add a single-screen arts cinema showing independent films.
In another part of White Plains, the developer Louis Cappelli is building a $300 million City Center, an entertainment, retail and residential complex with a 15-screen movie theater. It is expected to open next fall. The Galleria had a movie theater, but it closed in 1991.
The fifth floor that Mills plans to add to the Galleria would be smaller than the other floors at the mall. No date has been set for the new construction. The new owners of the Galleria said they were not planning to compete with any existing or planned shopping centers in White Plains, including the nearby upscale mall, The Weschester. "We're not going to turn the Galleria into something it's not," said Laurence C. Siegel, the chairman and chief executive officer of Mills. "It's kind of pointless for someone to buy the Galleria and try to replicate what The Westchester has done."
The Galleria has Macy's as an anchor and had J.C. Penney as another anchor, until recently. Sears is planning to occupy the space left vacant by J.C. Penney almost a year ago. By comparison, the anchors at The Westchester are Neiman Marcus and Nordstroms, stores that carry more expensive merchandise. 
The Galleria, which was completed in 1980, underwent an $8 million renovation in 1992. Gerald M. Cope, a Philadelphia architect who was responsible for the design changes then, observed at the time that most shopping centers need refurbishing every 10 or 12 years to keep pace with shifts in marketing and consumer trends. When it was built 22 years ago, the mall replaced an old city courthouse, but its presence downtown has been blamed for the difficulties experienced by once-prosperous merchants outside the mall who struggled economically on the streets nearby. 
Mills, a public company traded on the New York Stock Exchange typically builds its own shopping centers featuring outlet stores. The deal announced on Tuesday marks its first major foray into acquiring existing shopping centers. Mr. Douglass would not say whether discount outlets would be among a new tenant mix at the Galleria. Overall, the company plans to spend about $350 million to renovate and upgrade the newly acquired malls.
Mills owns 14 shopping centers representing 19 million square feet in 12 states. It has four projects under way or in development in the United States: in St. Louis and Cinncinati, and at the Meadowlands in New Jersey and The Piers in San Francisco. It has a downtown site under development in Chicago. Outside the United States it is developing a mall in Toronto and another in Madrid.
The Galleria and the other malls in its new acquisition package (which range in size from 637,000 square feet to 999,000 square feet) are smaller than Mills's other centers, which range in size from 1.2 million to 2.1 million square feet of space available to be leased.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Galleria mall, which is being bought and overhauled. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ugly Echoes; 
A Sanitized Past Comes Back to Haunt Trent Lott -- and America

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
LAST week Trent Lott, the incoming Senate majority leader, learned the truth of William Faulkner's dictum, so often applied to the South: "The past is never dead. It's not even past."
 But first, the nation needed a crash course in the rougher and more complicated parts of its own history. About the angry rise of the Dixiecrats in 1948. About the role that race played in the Republican realignment of the South. About Senator Strom Thurmond's long defense of segregation, and his final defection from the Democrats in 1964, after they pushed through the landmark civil rights bill opening public accommodations to blacks. About Mr. Lott's own history of opposing significant civil rights legislation. 
 What was striking was not that this past reared its troublesome head after Mr. Lott delivered his praise of Mr. Thurmond's 1948 presidential campaign as the nominee of the Dixiecrats, a "states' rights" party devoted to the preservation of a segregated South. What was striking was how long the reaction took to build, how distant the memories had become, how many politicians were initially caught off balance.
Americans often tend to sanitize their past, smooth the edges, develop a happy amnesia about the hardest parts, particularly when the subject is race. In the culture at large, the story of civil rights has become a simple morality tale of a great wrong righted by a just people through the intercession of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. But historians say the agonizing struggle and chaos of that era -- when the ultimate outcome did not seem inevitable, when the best way to get there was not apparent and yet many people still had to make a stand -- gets overlooked.
"What's fascinating about the Lott episode is it brings back the reality" that "people had to fight, some had to lose their lives, to win these rights," said Roderick Harrison, a sociologist at Howard University and an official with the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research group that focuses on issues facing black Americans. "That it was bitterly resisted. That Martin Luther King, who is now sanctified, was looked at as a dangerous radical."
The urge to tidy up the story is strong. Consider Mr. Thurmond, who was bid a sentimental farewell from the Senate this month as a kind of national grandpa, the long, morally ambivalent arc of his career turned into an uplifting narrative of a man who changed with the times. "Life is easier if there are no former segregationists around," said David J. Garrow, a civil rights historian. 
Even Dr. King, who now looms as an immense figure in popular history, has been blurred, transformed into a smooth icon of racial brotherhood, rather than the more difficult figure who also challenged the political establishment on the Vietnam War and economic inequity.
Part of the blurring of that era is explained by simple demographics: more than half of all Americans alive today weren't even born in 1964; nearly 80 percent weren't born in 1948.
"I know where I was when I heard of King's assassination, Robert Kennedy's, Malcolm X's," Mr. Harrison said. "These kinds of things are indelible. It is quite different when you are seeing things as historical events."
Moreover, James W. Loewen, a sociologist at Catholic University, argues that such history is often taught "as a parade of dead facts," drained of its relevance, because "teaching the past with relevance to the present is intrinsically controversial." For example, he said, many high school history textbooks skirt the subject of how the modern Republican Party benefited in the South from the votes of defecting Democrats angry over civil rights.
There are, in fact, reasons for both parties to step lightly over this history. Before it adopted a civil rights plank in 1948, the Democratic Party was, for many years, the "white South's instrument for pursuing the goals of white supremacy," as Merle Black, a political scientist at Emory University, put it.
Against this backdrop, the furor over Mr. Lott ultimately became a national tutorial. Addressing a 100th birthday party for Mr. Thurmond on Dec. 5, Mr. Lott, a lifelong Mississippian, declared of his state: "When Strom Thurmond ran for president, we voted for him. We're proud of it. And if the rest of the country had followed our lead, we wouldn't have had all these problems over all these years, either."
Mr. Lott said he was simply trying to praise a retiring colleague on his birthday. He maintained that he had made a poor choice of words, but that it was a "mistake of the head -- and not the heart." He insisted he was trying to honor Mr. Thurmond for his work on national defense and fiscal matters, not his defense of segregation. Republicans grumbled that the controversy was fanned by Democrats eager to wound an incoming majority leader after they had suffered big losses in the midterm election.
IT took time for the backlash to develop. As Alan Brinkley, a historian at Columbia University, put it, "you had to know something" about the Dixiecrats, who captured 92 percent of the white vote in Mississippi in 1948, to understand the provocative nature of Mr. Lott's remarks. It took five days for Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, to denounce his comments, and seven days for President Bush to do the same.
"Different Americans reacted differently," said Julian Bond, chairman of the N.A.A.C.P., and a professor at American University and the University of Virginia. "Black Americans were angry. White Americans were ashamed. And sometimes, shame makes you push the memory away." He added, "As a nation we're not comfortable with this memory."
Representative John Lewis, the Georgia Democrat who was on the front lines of the civil rights movement, agreed that Mr. Lott's casual endorsement of the Dixiecrats ultimately "touched a raw nerve." He was a child in Alabama during the 1948 campaign, but said he remembered it well. 
"Strom Thurmond walked out of the convention in 1948, and the Dixiecrats met in Birmingham, Ala., where he was nominated. It was a period of tremendous fear on the part of African-Americans. There was just fear."
BY week's end, the new majority leader was fighting for his political life, apologizing again, with his political record on civil rights coming under intense scrutiny. "Let me be clear," Mr. Lott said Friday night. "In celebrating his life, I did not mean to suggest in any way that his views of over 50 years ago on segregation were justified or right. It was wrong and immoral then and it is now. By the time I came to know Strom Thurmond -- some 40 years after he ran for president -- he had long since renounced many of the views of the past, repugnant views he had had."
In fact, Jack Bass, Mr. Thurmond's biographer, said he found it interesting that when the monument to Mr. Thurmond went up on the statehouse grounds in Columbia, S.C., a few years ago, "it did not mention his '48 presidential campaign, and he approved the wording of it."

HEADLINE: Rumors of Japan's Recovery Are, It Seems, Exaggerated 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO 

 BODY:
JAPAN'S lost decade is stretching toward a lost baker's dozen. Forecast growth of 1 percent in 2002 is expected to dribble down to 0.1 percent in 2003, according to a recent survey of economists.
 Political gridlock blocks deregulation, smothering growth opportunities in health, education, housing and travel. As tax revenue dwindles to half of government expenditures, elderly conservative legislators cling to the ancien regime by printing more and more bonds. And the fight against bad bank loans looks like a frantic scene from "The Sorcerer's Apprentice" as deflation and economic stagnation create bad loans as fast as banks can write them off. 
 Japan will remain the world's second-largest economy for at least two decades, but it will not be the locomotive for a world recovery next year. Barring the unexpected, it will not be a caboose. Instead, it will be a series of well-appointed Pullman coaches, where the passengers sense that cracks are appearing in the wheels.
"Japan is like Germany, falling into a dependency on the American consumer," said Kathy Matsui, managing director of Goldman Sachs Japan Ltd. "The only way out is to deregulate. But deregulation is the last option for politicians."
Overpriced housing, overpriced recreation and a looming health care shortage for the growing legions of elderly all offer opportunities for growth if the nation chooses to tackle them. But the ruling Liberal Democratic Party has more members in Parliament over 70 than under 40. For the grandfathers wielding behind-the-scenes power in Parliament, Japan, with the world's longest life expectancies, looks pretty good today, compared with their childhoods in the 1940's and 1950's.
Today's politicians do not expect to be around when today's bills come due. The amount of government debt is the equivalent of 140 percent of gross domestic product, the highest ratio for a major market economy. All three leading New York bond rating agencies downgraded Japanese yen ratings this year.
The Japanese miracle was hailed as a triumph of the Japanese people. But the Japanese malaise is now the fault of outsiders. Tokyo's stock markets are dragged down by New York markets. Japan "imports deflation from China" -- a code phrase for the fact that Chinese workers will do the same assembly work as Japanese, but for 5 cents on the dollar.
Like alchemists, financial officials write lengthy newspaper essays, trying to divine a magic monetary formula that will turn recession into resurrection. Voices for deregulation are relegated to the political fringe.
Without much help from the government, Japan struggles to adjust to Asia's great economic fact of the 21st century -- the embrace of market economics by China, a nation with 10 times the population.
While the government worries about dropping prices, the people worry about dropping salaries. White-collar incomes have fallen for 21 months. Summer and winter bonuses, responsible for as much as a third of incomes, are down by a record 5 percent. Next year, the government plans to cut some civil service pay and retirement allowances.
More significant, new workers are having a hard time finding well-paying jobs. In a neat switch, the latest government statistics show that in August there were 420,000 fewer full-time jobs than a year earlier, and 400,000 additional temporary jobs. 
Unemployment is expected to creep up to 6 percent next year, from 5.5 percent now, a post-World War II record. Unofficial unemployment is already at European levels, around 8.5 percent.
If a Dow Jones survey of economists, which pinned growth at 0.1 percent next year, comes true, 2002 will be remembered as Japan's shortest recovery since the war.
"The depth and duration of the next downturn will be shallower and milder than in the last three recessions of the 1990's," forecasts Mikihiro Matsuoka, economist for Deutsche Securities in Tokyo. "Unless deflation is prevented, the disposal of bad loans will be an endless pain."
Kenneth S. Courtis, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs Asia, is one of many foreign financial players who are quietly voting with their feet, devoting more and more time to China and less and less to Japan. 
Bad debts are paralyzing Japan's banking system "in a way which hasn't happened in a major economy since the system broke down in the 1930's," Mr. Courtis said. "Remember Thailand? When it imploded it shook markets from London to Wall Street, yet Japan's economy is 46 times larger."

HEADLINE: In Euro Zone, Woes Abound 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT 

 BODY:
IF one were to judge Europe's fledgling monetary union by its ability to generate economic growth in member countries, one would have to judge it a keen disappointment.
 The fastest-growing large economy in Europe is Britain, which has so far refused to adopt the euro, the common currency shared by 12 nations, preferring its sterling instead. Germany, home of the European Central Bank and the anchor of the euro zone, is the Continent's economic laggard, with growth for next year projected to be barely 1 percent. 
 Defenders of the euro warn against drawing too many conclusions from this comparison. Germany, and to a lesser extent France and Italy, have structural problems in their labor markets and welfare systems that Britain tackled two decades ago during the free-market revolution of Margaret Thatcher. 
While German leaders seem paralyzed by their country's woes, France has made recent strides in shaking loose its corporate sector, emerging as a modest beacon in Europe's gray economic landscape.
Still, Europe's transition to a monetary union has imposed unique restrictions on governments, tying them to a regionwide monetary policy and a set of fiscal guidelines that require that they keep their deficits below a ceiling and balance their budgets by 2006.
"If you join the union, you automatically lose autonomy in monetary policy and a great deal of flexibility in fiscal policy," said David Walton, chief European economist at Goldman, Sachs in London. Britain must consider this when taking up the issue of joining next year, he said
The European Commission recently reduced its forecast for 2003 growth in the euro zone, to 1.8 percent from 2.9 percent. Even that meager performance is contingent on stock markets and oil prices remaining stable -- no small assumption given the tension between the United States and Iraq.
In Germany, which accounts for a third of the output of the monetary union, the biggest question is whether it will escape its second recession in a year. Norbert Walter, the chief economist at Deutsche Bank, predicts that it will slip back into the red by the end of this year.
"We are very close to hitting the wall," Mr. Walter said. "2003 will be the most challenging period of the postwar era for Germany."
Germany's troubles have deep implications for its next-door neighbors and trading partners, Austria and the Netherlands. Larger economies, like France and Italy, are somewhat less vulnerable, while some Central European countries have benefited from Germany's high labor costs, as foreign companies migrate east in search of better opportunities.
A chronically weak Germany, however, could act as a substantial drag on Europe. Mr. Walton of Goldman, Sachs noted that from 1997 to 2002, the monetary union, not including Germany, grew at an annual rate of 2.6 percent. Adding in Germany, with its annual growth rate of only 1.6 percent, pulled down Europe's five-year performance to 2.3 percent.
The trouble is, Continental Europe's next-largest economies, France and Italy, are also sputtering. Goldman, Sachs forecasts growth of just 0.9 percent for Italy next year, while France is expected to grow 1.7 percent.
Recognizing the sluggish trend, the European Central Bank reduced interest rates by half a percentage point on Dec. 5. But economists note the impossibility of setting up a monetary policy that suits the needs of all 12 countries, which are growing at different rates and face different inflation concerns.
With Germany, France, and Italy all in bad odor with the European Commission because of their higher-than-expected deficits, there is also little the governments can do to jump-start their economies.
The architects of the European Union may nurture ambitions to build the world's largest economic block. But for now at least, Europe remains dependent on the United States to lift it out of its torpor.

HEADLINE: China's Hot, at Least for Now 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI 

 BODY:
CHINA's economy has defied the worldwide slowdown and continued its long streak of rapid growth, raising expectations that it has begun to pull its weight as an engine for Asia and the world.
 With the United States, Europe and Japan all experiencing sluggish growth, China is now expected to expand by a robust 8 percent this year, fueled by a surge in exports, soaring foreign investment and a housing boom. 
 Even if growth cools next year, as most economists predict, the country has begun to rival Japan as the pivotal player in Asia's economy. It has become the largest export market for both South Korea and Taiwan, for example, and has elbowed out Japan to become Asia's biggest exporter to the United States. 
"China has already become the largest market for several East Asian countries," said Nicholas Lardy, a leading expert on China's economy at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "It has become deeply integrated with the region and to an extent is pulling all its neighbors along with it."
Over all, China's economy lags far behind those of Japan and the United States. Its output is about a quarter of Japan's and about a ninth that of the United States. Even if China continues to grow much more quickly, it will take until the middle of the century before it becomes the world's largest economy.
Beijing has also moved exceedingly slowly to tackle the woes of its state banking system and to dismantle money-losing state enterprises. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development estimates that both sectors will drag down economic growth the next few years. Some economists argue that bad debts pose a severe long-term threat to China.
Yet those problems have been around for many years, and they have not stopped China from beginning to realize its potential. This year, it appears set to attract a record $50 billion in foreign investment, multiples more than the amount received by any other developing country and perhaps more than the United States.
Much of this investment has gone into bolstering China's position as the world's assembly line. It is now a leader in almost every category of manufactured goods, from shoes to semiconductors.
China produces so much, in fact, that some economists say it has helped create a glut of industrial products that has undermined prices -- hurting profits but helping consumers -- around the globe. China's home market has experienced falling prices for five consecutive years. So far this year, consumer prices have declined 1 percent.
Fierce competition and falling prices have forced multinational corporations to move production lines to China, which can make goods for less than its Asian neighbors can. So, its growth has come partly at the expense of the region. Still, about half of its exports, or about $275 billion last year, consists of products made in China by foreign companies or joint ventures of Chinese and foreign companies.
China has also begun pulling in imports at a record pace. Under the terms of its entry to the World Trade Organization last year, Beijing agreed to reduce tariffs sharply. They now average 15 percent, about a fourth of their peak level in the 1980's. It must reduce them further, to 9 percent on average, by 2005.
One sign of its growing importance to the world economy: China passed the United States this year as the world's largest importer of steel, helping absorb some global overcapacity. China already produces more steel than Japan and America combined, but a building boom and a surge in auto production led to imports of 23 million metric tons in the nine months ended in September, compared with 22 million tons for the United States in the period.
Or consider Asia's tourist industry. The number of visitors to Southeast Asia from both Japan and the United States has fallen below the levels of six years ago, according to Singapore government statistics. But Chinese mainlanders are traveling like never before, with the number doubling the last six years and continuing to grow despite the terrorist attacks in 2001.

HEADLINE: International Business; 
For Canadians, A Porous Border

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO 

 BODY:
DAVID L. MACDONALD prefers not to tell his American customers that Softchoice, the technology reseller where he is president, is a Canadian company.
 "We're known as a North American company," Mr. MacDonald said in an interview. He tells Americans instead that the headquarters are in Toronto. "Most Americans view Toronto as a great city," he said. 
 With 27 of its 32 sales outlets and 70 percent of its sales in the United States, Softchoice is one of a growing band of companies that happen to be based in Canada but pay increasingly less attention to the border.
Some, like the auto parts maker Magna International, the aluminum producer Alcan and the gold miner Barrick Gold, now report financial results only in United States dollars. A growing number also use American as well as Canadian accounting principles in their financial statements.
The number of Canadian companies listed on stock exchanges in the United States has risen from 130 to 240 in the last decade. According to a recent study on North American economic integration by the Bank of Montreal, Canadian companies raised more money outside than inside Canada last year, most of it in the United States.
Citing lower trade barriers and improved transport and communications links between the countries, Tim O'Neill, Bank of Montreal's chief economist, said in an interview: "What you're talking about is treating North America as a single economic entity. In industries where it makes sense to operate as if the border wasn't there, that's increasingly what you're going to see." Mr. O'Neill, whose office is in Toronto, was recently elected president of the National Association of Business Economists, based in Washington.
Canada's shipments to the United States totaled almost 85 percent of total exports in the first nine months of this year, up from 73 percent in 1988, when the two countries signed their first free-trade deal. The North American Free Trade Agreement, which also includes Mexico, took effect six years later.
Canadian National Railway, based in Montreal, has bought two railroads in the United States in the last three years. More than half its revenue now comes from crossborder or domestic American traffic.
Canadian National, which calls itself North America's Railroad, is the only railroad on the continent with tracks linking the Atlantic, the Pacific and the Gulf of Mexico.
IPSCO, a steel maker, had its head office in Regina, Saskatchewan, but moved its main executive offices to Lisle, Ill., two years ago. Seventy percent of IPSCO's assets are in the United States, it reports in United States dollars and its stock is listed on both the New York and Toronto exchanges.
Since 1996, Canada's five big banks have spent 13 billion Canadian dollars ($8.3 billion) on acquisitions south of the border. For instance, Toronto-Dominion Bank bought Waterhouse Securities Inc., now TD Waterhouse, one of the biggest discount brokerage firms, and Royal Bank of Canada paid 2.3 billion Canadian dollars ($1.4 billion) for Centura Banks Inc., of Rocky Mount, N.C.
Reflecting their broadening horizons, several banks have dropped the Canadian part of their names for day-to-day business. Toronto-Dominion these days usually calls itself TD Bank Financial Group, and Bank of Montreal, which owns Harris Bank in Chicago, has become the BMO Financial Group.
Still, even as these companies spread their wings across the border, a vigorous debate has erupted here over whether North American integration is doing Canadian business more harm than good.
Over the last three years, more than 60 of Canada's biggest companies have disappeared through mergers and acquisitions, with more than half of them taken over by foreign, mostly American, companies. Gordon M. Nixon, Royal Bank's chief executive, told a business group in Montreal earlier this year, "We should be asking why many of our industry leaders are being consolidated rather than doing the consolidating, why we are losing head offices at such an alarming rate, and what is the cost."
But Thomas d'Aquino, president of the Canadian Council of Chief Executives, based in Ottawa, said in an interview that taking into account the size of the two economies, Canadian companies have been far more active acquirers in the United States than American companies have in Canada.
"Far from being timorous little mice waiting for the cat to come and eat us," he said, "we have been remarkable for acquisitions south of the border." 
Mr. d'Aquino said that his council's members, who head Canada's biggest corporations, are strong proponents of even more free trade with the United States. The council and its American counterpart, the Business Roundtable, are considering the merits of a North American customs union, with a common external tariff, and the elimination of antidumping and countervailing-duty laws between the countries.
For now, however, many differences remain in laws and business practices. Jack M. Mintz, president of the CD Howe Institute, a policy research group based in Toronto, said, "We now have what's called a North American company, but in practice, instead of 10 different provinces and 3 territories in Canada, they have to think of 63 different jurisdictions."
Softchoice's Web site is divided into American and Canadian sections, and users switching from one to the other are warned that "you will lose your shopping cart and some products may not be available in the other country." Mr. MacDonald says he has also learned that being a North American company means "you have to be sensitive, like don't plan anything around Thanksgiving weekend."

HEADLINE: If There's a Global Rebound, The U.S. Will Have to Lead It 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
IN the election for the country most likely to drive a global economic recovery, only one candidate is receiving any votes: the United States.
 It does not matter that the nation's growth was just moderate this year, with more of the same expected for 2003 -- Britain, France, Germany and Japan all performed worse. Only China is emerging as a formidable contender, but its time to seize the limelight may still be several years away. 
 "There's very little chance that you're going to get a global recovery led by anybody except the United States," said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, chief economist of Salomon Smith Barney. Europe's economies, he said, underperformed throughout the recent economic cycle. Limping Japan, which once contributed to the expansion of the global economy until it fell into a slump in the early 1990's, is still hampering growth in Asia, he added. 
Among wealthy countries, only Canada and Australia will grow faster than the United States in 2002 and 2003, according to most forecasters. Yet their economies are far too small to pull the rest of the world along by investing in industries abroad and by importing goods and services. Combined, they are worth only one-seventh as much as the United States.
The lack of speedy growth in Japan and Western Europe is a source of consternation for John B. Taylor, the under secretary of the Treasury for international affairs. "Every country in the world should grow faster than the United States," he said.
Bad policies have slowed several big economies down, Mr. Taylor explained. "The Bank of Japan has made conditions very difficult for growth in Japan," he said. Without fixing the downward spiral of prices, he said, the country cannot expect to revive.
Germany, Mr. Taylor continued, has failed to duplicate American gains in productivity, the amount of goods and services workers can generate in a set period of time. He also criticized restrictions on hiring and firing, saying they make Germany's economy unresponsive to changing conditions.
Germany, France and the rest of the euro-currency countries may also be held back by overly conservative monetary policy, said David Dodge, the governor of Canada's central bank. "Obviously, they are running considerably below capacity," he said. He suggested that the European Central Bank could lower interest rates without raising the threat of inflation, but he bemoaned the imperfections of the regional system. "You've got monetary policy which is too tight for Germany and too loose for Ireland."
Though there may be only lethargy across the Atlantic, across the Pacific there is a flicker of hope -- one that promises to burst into a blaze. "There is another huge driver out there in Asia," said Gerard J. Kleisterlee, president and chairman of Royal Philips Electronics of the Netherlands. "It's called China."
Official figures for economic growth in China have averaged from 7 percent to 8 percent, adjusted for inflation, in the last several years. Measured in dollars, the Chinese economy is only about one-ninth the size of the United States'. It is about half the size when adjusted for differences in prevailing prices. China's biggest import partners include Japan, Taiwan, South Korea and the United States. But imports amount to about 5 percent of China's gross national product, versus 11 percent in the United States, and living standards are only about one-eighth as high.
China might not yet be ready to power economic growth abroad, but companies from around the world are already latching onto the growth potential of its market. Carlos Ghosn, president of Nissan Motor, said that China's demand for motor vehicles had risen faster than anyone expected. More than three million units have been sold this year, with Nissan's own sales up 80 percent. By 2010, Mr. Ghosn predicted, China would demand five million units a year.
With China's entrance into the World Trade Organization, tapping the country's market should become easier. But Mr. Ghosn warned that companies that did not already have good relations with the Chinese government might have a hard time entering the fray. 
In addition to emphasizing China, Mr. Kleisterlee said, Philips is developing new products for India and other big markets with expanding middle classes. Mr. Ghosn said that Iran and Iraq, which he expects to become commercially inclined democracies, could join that group before too long. Brazil, despite questions surrounding its new populist leadership, could also present valuable opportunities once its economy stabilizes, Mr. Dodge said.
For at least the next couple of years, though, the onus of global economic leadership rests squarely on the United States. That role may come at a cost.
The trade deficit, which has risen for a decade to set new records, can increase only if the United States continues its importing spree and remains the most attractive country for foreign investment. If Mr. Taylor's contention -- that every country should grow faster than this one -- ever comes true, that status will change.
At that point, which may come far in the future, foreigners will prefer to put their financial capital elsewhere. The United States will lose a crucial source of financing for investment and will need to save more, rather than consume more, to keep growing.
With less demand for American stocks and bonds, there will be less demand for the dollars needed to buy them. The dollar will therefore lose ground in currency markets. Though a weaker dollar would spur exports, it could also push prices up in the United States, leading the Federal Reserve Board to clamp down on the economy for a prolonged period. But as foreigners switch to buying America's goods and services -- things with real, intrinsic value -- instead of its securities, the trade deficit will disappear.
Mr. Ghosn, whose company is based in Japan, said he was not worried about that turn of events because of Nissan's productive capacity in the United States. If the dollar tumbles, the cost of a car built in the United States will not change much. Walter B. Wriston, former chairman and chief of Citicorp, went a step further. The trade deficit, he said, is one of "the two numbers that mean the least," along with the federal budget deficit.

HEADLINE: Technology & Media: Advertising; 
People Are Talking About Looser Wallets

BYLINE:  By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
VANILLA will be the scent of the year for 2003, according to Mintel, a research company, and citrus the flavor of the year. Green in all shades will be the color in home furnishings for 2003, the trade association Cotton Inc. says. But when it comes to forecasts for advertising spending, the crystal ball clouds over.
 As one of the most unsettled years in memory comes to a bumpy conclusion, Madison Avenue is anticipating an improvement; big advertisers -- buoyed by an economy that by some measures appears to be emerging from its sluggishness -- are looking to increase their marketing budgets. 
 So most forecasts call for a moderate increase in ad spending next year of 3 percent to 4 percent over this year, which is likely to end with a gain of 2 percent to 3 percent from 2001. The dean of forecasters, Robert J. Coen, senior vice president at the giant New York media agency Universal McCann, is more optimistic, predicting an increase of 5 percent in 2003 from 2002. 
The recovery in ad spending may be uneven, however, as it was this year. Some marketers in categories like automobiles, entertainment and fast food reopened their wallets faster than others and allocated ad dollars to some media, like television and radio, ahead of others. That is one reason several forecasters like John Perriss, chief executive at another media giant, ZenithOptimedia in London, are projecting an increase of 1 percent to 2 percent in 2003, with a full recovery not until 2004.
There is also enough general uncertainty, centered on a possible war with Iraq and further terrorist attacks, to cause the upbeat predictions to be qualified with phrases evocative of the old railroad timetable admonition that train schedules are subject to change without notice.
"We all live with our fingers crossed today," said Gary Fries, president and chief executive at the Radio Advertising Bureau in New York, the trade group for local and national radio stations and networks.
"Planning seems to be getting back to normal and confidence seems to be returning," he added, "short of a devastating event." Such events caused ad spending in 2001, already lagging because of a faltering economy before Sept. 11, to decline 6.5 percent from the record results of 2000. That was the steepest percentage decline since the Depression year of 1938, when ad spending dropped 8.1 percent.
Even with the gains expected for 2002 and 2003, "we're still behind 2000," said O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive at the American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York, the industry trade organization. "But up is still better than down. It could be a lot worse."
"The term I use about next year is 'reasonably optimistic,' " he added. "It won't be gangbusters, but it will be better than 2002."
Explaining his rational exuberance, Mr. Drake said that "employment has finally stabilized and agencies will start to do some hiring."
Even the markets "that have been hardest hit with cutbacks, New York and San Francisco, are starting to come back," he said.
"I think it's going to be O.K.," Mr. Drake added, with one large caveat: "If we go to war with Iraq, all bets are off."
Assuming no war or terror, Lauren Rich Fine, the analyst who follows the advertising industry for Merrill Lynch, said that "it feels as if there's going to be enough of an ad recovery that we could measure it." She forecasts an increase in ad spending of 4 percent next year, compared with a projected gain of 0.7 percent for 2002 over 2001.
"The big theme for me is that a lot of industries have excess capacity in an environment of low inflation," she added, and that "could lead to extra spending in advertising to gain more market share."
Such spending is already coming from marketers in crowded categories that also include banks, drugs, health care, mortgage lenders, packaged foods and retailers.
"Advertising is strengthening across categories," said Mr. Fries of the radio bureau, "which creates pressure on demand." He is predicting a percentage increase in spending for radio commercials in 2003 "in the high single digits." So far this year, ad spending for radio is up 5 percent.
For online advertising, a forecast from eMarketer, a research company in New York, puts the increase in spending at 5 percent next year. Though not robust, that would be the first percentage gain since 2000."Overhype of the Internet is a wound that hasn't been fully recovered from," said David Hallerman, senior analyst at eMarketer, "but with the ad industry strengthening along with the economy, there will be relief" for the interactive media.
One reason for the slow rebound is that younger executives "more comfortable with the Internet" are moving into senior posts at consumer product companies, Mr. Hallerman added, "and that 'comfort factor' cannot be underestimated."
Whether or not paired with the Internet, television advertising has been the standout story of 2002. Robust demand for commercial time, particularly on national broadcast networks, began in the spring and gained momentum through the year. Almost every forecast for 2003 includes similarly strong gains for television ad spending.
It's a "flight to safety," said Chris Rohrs, president of the Television Bureau of Advertising in New York, the trade association for local TV stations, echoing an observation made by many executives and analysts.
By that, Mr. Rohrs said, he means that when ad dollars are scarce and marketers are "desperate to make sure what they do works," they tend to shun the more experimental media -- even if they cost less -- in favor of proven mainstays.
Television may be "the most expensive in raw dollars," he added, but it is also "the least expensive in cost efficiency."
TV, along with radio, also benefits in uneasy climates because of the shorter lead times required to book spots. Conversely, that works against print media, particularly monthly magazines, which in some instances have closing dates up to three months before they are published. No surprise, then, that through the first 11 months of 2002, magazine ad pages fell 4.5 percent from the period a year ago, according to the Publishers Information Bureau.
"People say, 'When are magazines going to catch up?' " said Ellen Oppenheim, executive vice president and chief marketing officer of the Magazine Publishers of America in New York. "It's always a little bit difficult to predict because of the closing dates for the monthlies."
"We're encouraged," she added, "that recent months have indicated an upward trend" in categories including magazines for parents, teenagers and young men, as well as those focused on the home, "which are benefiting from the 9/11 nesting effect."
In another encouraging sign for magazines, several are increasing circulation guaranteed to advertisers in 2003.
For all the positive indicators, the twin shadows of war and terror tower over everyone's forecast. What happens, for example, "if people spend more time listening to news on AM radio than to music on FM radio?" or "if everyone turns to CNN?" asked Michael J. Russell, the advertising analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York.
Without domestic terror or an overseas war, Mr. Russell forecasts ad spending to increase 4.2 percent in 2003.
"We had a couple of years when we overindexed," he said, referring to the unusually robust gains of 1999 and 2000, "and we had a couple of years we underindexed," referring to 2001 and 2002.
"Now we're looking right down the middle," he added. "In these uncertain times, I don't know if it's encouraging as much as reassuring."
