HEADLINE: Patents; 
After 13 years of ruminating, the UnitedStates agrees to join a global trademark system.

BYLINE:  By Sabra Chartrand; Patents may be viewed on the Web at www.uspto.gov or may be ordered through the mail, by patent number, for $3 from the Patent and Trade mark Office, Washington, 20231.

 BODY:
AFTER 13 years, the United States is finally joining a one-stop shopping system for managing trademarks that more than 65 other countries have adopted since 1989. But even though the new rules had vigorous support among American trademark holders and applicants, and even though they have been practically inevitable for over a decade, they will not go into effect until November 2003.
 The new procedures are called the Madrid Protocol, after an earlier treaty drawn up in 1896. Under them, trademark applicants need file only one application to win protection in the countries belonging to the pact, instead of having to file separate applications with each nation. 
 This is a sweeping change for American applicants. Under the new system, an applicant can file an international application with the United States Patent and Trademark Office. On the form, he would indicate the countries belonging to the Madrid Protocol in which he wanted protection. The form can be submitted in French or English, eliminating the need for applying in multiple languages. The Patent and Trademark Office then forwards the application to the World Intellectual Property Organization, and WIPO sends out an international registration for the mark.
That is not the end of the process, however. WIPO will then send the application to the relevant countries, where trademark examiners will analyze the application. Each country may take 18 months to make a final decision, or longer if the application is opposed. If the trademark is approved, the Madrid Protocol gives it a life span of 10 years plus one renewal, for which an owner must pay a $100 renewal fee.
It is a chain of paperwork, but is still an easier, cheaper and more efficient way for trademark holders to secure worldwide protection than submitting separate applications to each country involved. For small companies and independent inventors the rule should make it feasible to invest in international trademarks by significantly reducing the red tape, local agents, language requirements and fees involved.
In 2000, the government estimated that an American trademark owner who wanted to register his mark in 10 countries faced $14,000 in fees for 10 separate applications. It said the Madrid Protocol would bring that cost down to about $4,700.
But the new rules also mean that trademark applicants will have to search not only United States trademark archives but an international register of archives from all Madrid Protocol countries when checking whether the mark they want already belongs to someone else.
"It is really going to make changes in terms of the way searches are done," predicted Susan Reiss, a trademark lawyer at in New York. Ms. Reiss is also editor in chief of an industry journal, The Trademark Reporter.
"Right now, if you have a trademark in the United States, your main concern is what marks are in use here," she continued. "Now it means United States trademark owners must be very much concerned with what's out there in the world. They need to decide whether to file in the United States and extend their application to the Madrid Protocol."
Some nations have looser trademark requirements than the United States, so American applicants can often obtain broader trademark protection abroad than here. Thus, trademark lawyers will have to consider whether it makes sense for their clients to apply for a one-stop international application under American laws, or to approach more liberal countries directly.
In addition, the protocol retains a five-year period during which any successful challenge to an original trademark application would nullify all international trademarks.
"For the first five years, your international registration is wholly dependent on your home-base application," Ms. Reiss explained. "If I could find a grounds of attack and have it canceled, then all the countries to which you have extended your trademark would fall, too."
Those 60 applications could still "be converted into national registrations" in each country, she added.
Although the protocol had vigorous support from business and industry, and from organizations like the International Trademark Association, which sought greater overseas protection for brand-name goods and services, it was also so tangled in American foreign and economic policy that it languished in Congress through three administrations. For several years, the sticking point was a provision giving the European Union a vote along with its 15 member nations. The United States said that gave Europe a double vote and set a precedent for other treaties. So for more than 10 years the Madrid Protocol led to little more than rumor, debate, lobbying and frustration among supporters.
In February 2000, the voting dispute was officially resolved to American satisfaction when the idea of giving the European Union a separate vote was dropped. Protocol supporters stepped up their lobbying and everyone agreed there was no significant remaining opposition in Congress, but it still took more than two years before the United States formally joined the protocol.
Finally, in October, President Bush signed the Justice Department Reauthorization Act, and buried in it, the Madrid Protocol Implementation Act. The law gives the Patent and Trademark Office at least a year to put the new rules into effect.
"We will definitely take the whole year," said Lynne Beresford, the deputy commissioner for trademark policy, with a planned starting date of Nov. 2, 2003. The agency must write new regulations and it is planning to set up a new computer system to handle international applications. Although applications for a basic American trademark can still be filed either on paper or electronically, the international ones will have to be filed electronically.
"We've been talking about the Madrid Protocol for 10 years, and it wasn't happening," Ms. Beresford added. "So when do you decide to put the people and time into it? The answer is: not until you have the law."
The changes will give American trademark holders "layers upon layers upon layers of protection," Ms. Reiss said. "Now it's possible to get a community trademark in the 15 countries of the European Union. So a company could have a national registration, a C.T.M. and an international registration.
"The bottom line is, the Madrid Protocol should help small trademark owners," she added, "because individuals and small entities that can't have all these layers will opt for international protection, to the extent that 60 countries is worldwide."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Nine Tales From the Underside, Where the Talk Is Terse

BYLINE:  By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
WHEN THE WOMEN
COME OUT TO DANCE
By Elmore Leonard
228 pages. William Morrow. $24.95.
 Let the last line of dialogue from Elmore Leonard's new short-fiction collection sum up Mr. Leonard's great gift: "He could tell a story." More precisely, he can invent coolheaded characters who leap off the page, equip them with pricelessly terse dialogue and dream up the kinds of plots that might have worked for O. Henry, if O. Henry had had a serious interest in lowlife, double-crossing and crime. 
 The short-story format brings out these strengths to a surprising degree. Mr. Leonard's longer plots can resemble strings of interlocking vignettes, but the compact tales in his new collection carry no such baggage. Most are short and sweet, though this nine-part collection also includes two novellas. One of those, "Tenkiller," and the diabolical title story, "When the Women Come Out to Dance," are the only selections that have not been published before.
"When the Women Come Out to Dance" is a model of interpersonal relations, Leonard style. Mrs. Wasim Mahmood, who looks like Jill St. John (the author often uses real actors' appearances as shorthand), is hiring a maid. The setting is Palm Beach, but the new employee, Lourdes, comes from Cali, Colombia, a place well known for drug-related violence. What's more, Lourdes came to Florida as the mail-order bride of a Mr. Zimmer, who wound up buried in a pile of cement out by Hialeah.
"It's Ginger," Mrs. Mahmood says, introducing herself. "Well, actually it's Janeen, but all of my friends call me Ginger. The ones I have left." It develops that Ginger is a former stripper and that she is not one to mince words. She claims to be afraid of her husband, a Pakistani plastic surgeon. "A guy gets tired of his wife in Pakistan?" Ginger says. "He burns her to death. Or has it done. I'm not kidding, he tells everyone her dupatta caught fire from the stove."
Lourdes observes, "Ah, that's why you don't cook." 
Soon Ginger is dropping hints as to what she wants. "How much does a load of concrete cost these days?" she wonders. She supposes that Lourdes knows how to make husbands disappear, and to some extent she's right. But Ginger, like an O. Henry heroine and most of the book's main characters, gets something slightly different from what she bargained for.
The main character in "Tenkiller" is a stuntman and rodeo rider whose actual name is Ben Webster. He took the Indian name of the title so that he could land a role in "Dances With Wolves," his first movie; since then, he has been shot in "Air Force One," run through with a sword in "The Mask of Zorro," stepped on in "Godzilla," and so on. He has also suffered in the real world, having very bad luck with women. This seems to be a Webster family curse.
Tenkiller's Webster family heritage also includes a pecan farm in Oklahoma. And when he comes home to the place, he finds unexpected no-good tenants on the premises. It turns out that the farm has been sublet to them by a real estate agent named Denise, who was known as "Denise the piece" when Tenkiller had a high school crush on her. Now the two are reunited in such a mad, hasty tryst that they have time for small talk only afterward. That talk is economical, and pure Leonard, too: "You look better than ever."
"I like your hair like that."
"You're not married, are you?"
"Would it matter?"
Sudden passion also figures in this book's other novella, "Fire in the Hole," set in Kentucky coal-mining country. Raylan Givens and Boyd Crowder once dug coal together; now Raylan is a lawman, Boyd a neo-Nazi. ("Has his own army now, bunch of serious morons sieg-heilin' each other?" Raylan says.) And things get complicated between them after Boyd's brother, Bowman, is shot by Bowman's wife, Ava. Before killing him, she made him a big ham-and-yam dinner, because she wanted him sitting down.
Why did she do it? "He'd get on me for the least thing," Ava explains to Raylan, once these two develop a shared attraction. "Like if he found a hair in his baked possum? Or I didn't get out all the scent glands?" Mr. Leonard has a classic deadpan way of making such details funny and credible, too.
"Fire in the Hole," like most of the stories here, boils down to a showdown between two highly determined characters, ending in something unexpected. So does "Karen Makes Out," featuring the same hot-blooded United States marshal who was a character in "Out of Sight." Another of Mr. Leonard's novels, "Tishomingo Blues," is evoked by "Chickasaw Charlie Hoke," a short story that contains the seeds of that book. And in "Sparks" Mr. Leonard presents his own abbreviated version of the film "The Last Seduction." A woman said to resemble Linda Fiorentino in that film works a kind of witchcraft on the fire inspector trying to determine why she burned down her house in Malibu.
There are some oddities here: "Hanging Out at the Buena Vista," a tight and very brief sketch of the pragmatic courtship of two elderly people; "Hurrah for Capt. Early," in which a black soldier under Theodore Roosevelt's command at San Juan Hill contends with his white comrades' refusal to acknowledge him; and "The Tonto Woman," about a man named Ruben in Arizona and a white woman ostracized for her contact with Indians. In Mr. Leonard's witty, well-balanced scheme of justice, Ruben befriends the Tonto Woman and feels that it would be only fair to steal her husband's cattle at the end of the story.

HEADLINE: A 'New Economy' Editor at Time to Oversee AOL Integration 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CARR 

 BODY:
Time Inc. is expected to announce today that Ned Desmond, currently president of the company's Business 2.0 magazine, has been chosen to oversee the integration of Time Inc. content into the AOL service, according to company executives.
 As executive editor of Time Inc. Interactive, a new job, Mr. Desmond will move to the AOL unit's headquarters in Dulles, Va., where he will work closely with the online service's programming executives. 
 His presence there will represent a new level of cooperation between the often fractious divisions of the parent AOL Time Warner and further evidence that under the company's new management structure, Time Inc. expects to have a substantial hand in determining AOL's editorial direction.
Early this month, AOL Time Warner disclosed a plan in which content from Time Inc. magazines that particularly appeal to women, teenagers and children -- including People, Entertainment Weekly, InStyle, Teen People and Time for Kids -- would become available on the Web primarily through AOL.
Company officials, speaking in background interviews pending the announcement, said that Mr. Desmond had been selected as Time Inc.'s chief liaison with AOL because he had extensive relationships with much of the unit's business and editorial leadership along with experience in digital publishing at Infoseek and the Walt Disney Company.
Mr. Desmond will report to John Squires, an executive vice president at Time Inc., and John Huey, the editorial director, and will also have a yet-to-be determined reporting relationship with Ted Leonsis, the vice chairman of AOL. Although he will remain a Time Inc. employee, Mr. Desmond will be working with Jim Bankoff, executive vice president for operations at AOL, and David Gang, AOL's executive vice president for product marketing, on editorial programming for the entire service.
A senior business executive at Time Inc. said, "Ned has a great deal of credibility within Time Inc., but has spent enough time in the online world to have credibility at AOL as well."
As president and former editor of Business 2.0, one of the so-called new economy magazines, Mr. Desmond has had a close look at the exaggeration and subsequent disappointment of the digital revolution. A former bureau chief for Time magazine in New Delhi and Tokyo, he also covered Silicon Valley and the Japanese economy for Fortune magazine. 
Mr. Desmond served as vice president at Infoseek and played a central role in developing the Go.com portal for Disney, blending Disney's various brands onto a highly promoted and costly site that eventually failed. Time Inc. had its own lesson in the perils of online-content creation with Pathfinder, a $100 million attempt at a Web portal site that led to little more than unfavorable headlines.
Since the merger of AOL and Time Warner nearly two years ago, the relationship between Time Inc. and America Online has been a troubled one. Officials of Time Inc. considered the editorial programming at AOL generally an extension of marketing requirements and were not eager to put control of the magazine's content in AOL's hands. 
But the departure of Robert W. Pittman, the former chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner, and the appointment of Don Logan, the former Time Inc. chief, as chairman of the company's media and entertainment group, including the AOL service, has created a more cooperative relationship.
Executives at Time Inc. said that the appointment of Mr. Desmond, long a favorite of Mr. Huey and of Norman Pearlstine, editor in chief of Time Inc., indicated that Time Inc. was serious about improving the relationship and making content from the magazines a significant part of the proprietary service. They added that his role would include shaping the digital strategies of magazines, like Time and Sports Illustrated, that are not now scheduled to become part of AOL.
"In order to make those kind of changes happen, you have to have someone who can break down the inherent tribalism, title by title and discipline by discipline," an editorial executive at the company said. "It is unrelenting, difficult work, but this is not some midlevel initiative we are involved in. The impetus for all of this comes right from the top of the company."
Although Mr. Desmond has the confidence of the leadership at AOL Time Warner, it has been a rough ride at Business 2.0. Mr. Desmond was the founding editor as well as president of eCompany Now, which became Business 2.0 after Time Inc. acquired the magazine for $68 million in June 2001. As the digital economy began to fall apart, Business 2.0 suffered. In April Mr. Desmond was replaced as editor by Josh Quittner, a former technology editor of Time magazine.
In his new job, Mr. Desmond will be refereeing between the sometimes disparate interests of AOL and Time Inc. The magazine unit's editors are concerned with protecting journalistic brands that have been decades in the making, while AOL wants a splashy welcome screen with news from many different brands. Mark Golin, an AOL executive who has been on loan to Time Inc., will work closely with Mr. Desmond in developing approaches to content that aim to make AOL more than a service largely used for e-mail and chat. 
Ann S. Moore, chief executive of Time Inc., has made it clear she thinks that a true partnership with AOL -- what she calls "sharing, not synergy" -- is critical to both divisions. She has suggested in conversations with editorial and business executives that Time Inc.'s resources could be used to build up digital franchises like a beefed-up homework site on America Online or a college ranking system that would have user feedback and might rival that of U.S. News & World Report.

HEADLINE: Law Schools Urge Graduates to Start Small and Think Local 

BYLINE:  By GREG WINTER

 BODY:
Life for the partners of Cates, Katalinic & Lund holds little of the glamour one might expect from a career in law. Instead of lunches at Lutece, they caucus at the Palace Diner in Queens. Wooing clients means passing out fliers on street corners, not securing box seats at Madison Square Garden. To make ends meet, one partner stacks pipe and cleans the yard at a plumbing warehouse. Another handles urine samples in a hospital lab.
 A sign of failure, of a feeble economy, perhaps? Hardly. They are heeding the call of a growing pool of law schools, which are for the first time pointing graduates in a new direction and teaching them how to get there. Forget the lure of large firms, the security of a government post. Here is how to grapple "in the service of justice," as many of the schools put it, instead. 
 Convinced that corporate largess and government programs barely dent the nation's legal needs, the law schools are urging graduates to buck tradition, pass up big salaries and ignore mushrooming student debt to join tiny neighborhood practices or simply start their own, all with an eye toward charging no more than their clients can afford. 
This is not pro bono legal work; it is "low bono," a term the schools coined to define the atypical kind of law career they are training students for. While its practitioners do charge for their services, they are also dead set on turning no one away -- or at least as few as possible. 
"When you go into this kind of social justice law, it's really brutal and you're almost guaranteed to struggle for a couple of years before there's a light at the end of the tunnel," said Fred Rooney, director of the Community Legal Resource Network at City University of New York School of Law, from which the lawyers of the newly formed Cates, Katalinic & Lund graduated last May. "But if our graduates don't do it, the millions of people who cannot access justice in this country will continue to soar." 
The movement, primly called the consortium, started four years ago by CUNY, Northeastern University, the University of Maryland and St. Mary's Law School in Texas. (St. Mary's later dropped out.) Since then, it has drawn seven additional law schools to its ranks: the University of Michigan, Rutgers and Syracuse Law Schools, New York Law School, University of New Mexico School of Law, Thomas M. Cooley Law School and Touro Law School. It has elicited at least initial interest from 19 more.
Mixing foundation money with their own to go beyond the standard curriculum, the schools are teaching the nuts and bolts of running a business, setting up client referral networks for fledgling practitioners and holding seminars to tackle the mundane challenges of going it alone that are often considered superfluous to the study of law.
As further encouragement for the 200 or so followers they have picked up already, the consortium schools have given their graduates Palm organizers, paid for companies to help with their billing, and offered free legal research and even yoga and meditation classes, almost anything to help make life a little easier for those trying to hang out their shingles. 
"We're talking about training real community lawyers," said Stuart L. Deutsch, dean of the Rutgers School of Law in Newark. "The perception is that the solo practitioners are the ones who got C's, the second string who didn't excel enough to get to the big firms. We're trying to say that solo practice can be among the highest forms of public service, and is the only channel possible to serving low-income people."
True or not, there is little debate that most low-income clients, and many in the middle class, find lawyers well outside their financial reach. Even at the smallest of firms, the median hourly rate starts at roughly $130 an hour and passes $180, according to a 2002 survey by Altman Weil, a legal consulting company. For firms with more than 150 lawyers in tow, the range is from $200 to more than $320 an hour, the survey found, not counting the dinners, taxi rides and other extras that are often tacked onto the bill.
At those rates, perhaps it should come as no surprise that 71 percent of low-income people and 61 percent of moderate-income people with civil troubles end up without representation, according to the American Bar Association. For the truly poor, meaning they earn no more than $11,075 a year, there are government-financed legal aid agencies to turn to, 172 in all, but these offices are so overwhelmed that only one in five people who qualify for help actually gets any. 
By contrast, big law firms are slowly stepping up their commitment to free services, after 10 years of pulling back. Yet their lawyers still spend less than 42 hours a year doing pro bono work, far short of the profession's guidelines to perform at least 50 volunteer hours each year. Even during more charitable times, the bar association says, most of the free or less costly work is handled by small firms and solo practitioners, making them a natural target for the consortium's sights.
"A lot of students still go to law school because of their ideals, and they're willing to bite the bullet, drive old cars, not buy a home and keep living a student's life for a few more years until they get settled," said Lovely Dhillon, the former San Francisco assistant district attorney who heads the consortium. "It's incumbent on us to help them." 
The consortium certainly has a lot to overcome, most notably the pull of big law firms. Twenty years ago, three times as many law school graduates went into solo or tiny practices as went to firms with more than 100 lawyers, according to the National Association for Law Placement. By last year, the two poles had flip-flopped, with the biggest firms attracting 30 percent more graduates than the smallest, and given the difference in pay it is not hard to see why. 
Joining a firm with fewer than 10 lawyers means starting at $43,000 a year, the association says. The bigger a practice gets, though, the higher its starting salaries climb, topping out around $125,000 a year at the largest firms. Considering that law school tuitions have roughly doubled in the last decade, pushing the median student debt past $84,000, it is understandable why some question how far the consortium can spread. 
"It's a great idea, but the pressure of academic debt really leads people to big firms in big cities," said Theresa J. Bryant, executive director of the career development office at Yale Law School, which is not part of the consortium. "When you're standing $90,000 in debt, going small may present a bit of a challenge."
Fair enough, the consortium says. Not all graduates will be able to scrounge for the years it may take to build a clientele, nor should they. But since as many as 30 percent to 40 percent of the graduates at schools like CUNY go into small or solo practices within a few years of graduating, the deans argue, it seems folly not to teach them how to stay afloat financially and take on low-income clients at the same time. 
How do you advertise? How do you bill clients and, perhaps even trickier, get them to pay? How can you remain affordable and still pay your rent? What kind of office software will you need? How about malpractice insurance? Such are the sobering questions, rarely highbrow enough to find their way into legal pedagogy, that the consortium seeks to help their graduates tackle. 
"Important as they are, these issues are low on the academic pecking order, and not what get most faculty recognized," said Deborah L. Rhode, former president of the Association of American Law Schools and a professor of law at Stanford University, also outside the consortium. "The truth is, legal education is partially responsible for the disconnect between what ordinary Americans need and what educated lawyers can supply."
Even for the most intrepid and socially conscious of graduates, starting a practice requires a giant leap of faith, and more than a little guesswork. Charging sliding-scale fees means coming up with a new wage for almost every case one takes, and seldom can practitioners rely on anything more solid than their own judgment. 
"How much will we charge?" Tristan Da Cunha, one of the new graduates starting Cates, Katalinic & Lund asked with a shrug, furrowing his brow as if the question had never come up. "I think it's fair to say we'll be heavily discounted."

PERSON: Eli Ginzberg 

HEADLINE: Eli Ginzberg, 91, Economist at Columbia And Adviser to Eight Presidents, Is Dead 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT F. WORTH

 BODY:
Eli Ginzberg, an economist who taught at Columbia University for more than six decades, advised eight American presidents and led pioneering research efforts in employment and health care, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.
 Dr. Ginzberg first showed his bent for applied economics during World War II, when he moved from his home in New York to Washington and served the federal government in a variety of positions. He built on that experience for decades, supervising studies designed to reduce the waste of manpower, publishing many books and articles and later advising governments and corporations. 
 "What Eli had was an enormous command of the facts and a remarkably down-to-earth practical sense of what was possible, politically and economically," said Robert M. Solow, who received a Nobel in economics in 1987. "He was sort of the guardian of common sense in the areas of manpower problems and health care."
As a consultant to President Franklin D. Roosevelt on military personnel during the war, Dr. Ginzberg wrote a study that helped lead to the removal of 250,000 civilians from the Army payroll and the more efficient deployment of soldiers.
He also worked in the government's hospital division and the surgeon general's office in the War Department, where he coordinated the extensive medical preparations for the D-Day invasion of France in 1944. He was awarded the medal for Exceptional Civilian Service from the War Department in 1946.
After the war, he returned to teaching, and he served as director of staff studies at the National Manpower Council from 1952 until 1961. He wrote about the importance of integrating women and racial minorities into the work force, and in the early 1950's he played a role in the desegregation of the United States Army as an aide to Secretary of the Army Frank Pace Jr.
He also applied his knowledge of economics to the health care system, writing books and dozens of articles for publications like The New England Journal of Medicine and The Journal of the American Medical Association.
Eli Ginzberg was born on April 30, 1911, to Louis and Adele Ginzberg in New York City, where he grew up just a few blocks from Columbia University. His father, a professor at the Jewish Theological Seminary, was one of the foremost Talmudic scholars of the 20th century. Their home was a gathering place for renowned scholars, and that atmosphere helped inspire his own ambitions, Dr. Ginzberg later wrote. 
He attended DeWitt Clinton High School and Columbia University, where he stayed on to earn his doctorate in economics in 1934 and joined the faculty in 1935.
In that year, with the country in the grip of the Depression, he completed a yearlong tour of 40 American states. His observations formed the basis for a set of recommendations on reforming the regulatory and monetary systems, published in 1939 as "The Illusion of Economic Stability." 
After the war, he was appointed by President Harry S. Truman to represent the United States at a conference in May 1946 on victims of German actions who could not be repatriated. He also continued to provide advice to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who became president of Columbia in 1948.
In 1950, Dr. Ginzberg was appointed to the staff of the Conservation of Human Resources Project at Columbia's Graduate School of Business, a research effort founded by General Eisenhower that involved the federal government, business groups, foundations and trade unions. Dr. Ginzberg was a co-author of its first major study, "The Uneducated," which argued for a greater federal role in education.
In the early 1950's, Dr. Ginzberg was sent to Europe by the Pentagon to help break the resistance of the Army senior staff to desegregation. His first experience with Army segregation had come during the war, when he discovered a group of black and white wounded soldiers being treated in separate hospital wards in South Carolina. He ordered that the wards be integrated, leading to a complaint from the state's governor. He and his colleagues at the Conservation of Human Resources Project later wrote about the problems of the segregated Army in a three-volume study, "The Ineffective Soldier: Lessons for Management and the Nation."
Dr. Ginzberg continued to advise state and federal governments on health issues and advised presidents through Jimmy Carter. He also contributed many books on subjects like the supply of doctors and managed care, which he viewed skeptically.
Dr. Ginzberg was married in 1946 to Ruth Szold, who was an editor at the Conservation of Human Resources Project.
In 1974, he helped found the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a nonprofit group dedicated to testing rigorously public policy ideas on subjects like welfare and the reintegration of former prison inmates.
Like his parents, Dr. Ginzberg was active in Jewish causes, volunteering for the United Jewish Committee and serving as a member of the board of governors of Hebrew University in Jerusalem in the 1950's. The first of his two memoirs, "My Brother's Keeper," published in 1989, deals mostly with his family and his Jewish heritage. The second, "The Eye of Illusion," published in 1993, is mostly about his professional career.
Dr. Ginzberg's wife died in 1995. He is survived by his three children, Jeremy, of Portland, Ore.; Abigail, of Albany, Calif.; and Rachel, of Philadelphia, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: A Chance to Learn 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

DATELINE: GASTON, N.C. 

 BODY:
The first thing you notice about the school is how quiet it is. The kids are absorbed in their studies and except for the low roar of conversation in the cafeteria during lunch, or the enthusiastic screeching of band practice, you hardly hear a sound.
 The Gaston College Preparatory School in this rural town just across the border from Virginia is housed in a new low-rise building on land that until recently was a peanut and soybean farm. Farm equipment outlets and a cotton field or two line the roads leading to the school. 
 There are only two grades, fifth and sixth. A seventh and eighth grade will be added over the next two years.
I wanted to visit Gaston College Prep because I'd heard it was a remarkable school. It's in a region that is struggling economically and is not known for its academic excellence. Most of the students at the school are black and nearly all of them are poor. Most of the other schools available to them are burdened with problems that show no signs of easing.
At Gaston Prep, which the kids call G.C.P., the atmosphere is almost idyllic. The children are well behaved and the classroom work is intense. "We don't have any fighting here, or any of that picking-on-people stuff," said Shanequa High, a sixth-grader whose reading ability improved dramatically in just one year, and who was the lead dancer in the school's production of "The Lion King" last year.
Another student, 12-year-old Paris Gatling, said, "We're here to work, and we work hard."
Gaston Prep is one of 15 KIPP schools in the United States. KIPP is short for the Knowledge Is Power Program, an effort that began in Houston and has grown into one of the most energetic and academically sound public school programs in the nation.
The key to the success of the schools seems to be the requirement that there be a strong commitment in the very beginning by pupils, parents and a team of extremely dedicated teachers to put forth whatever effort is necessary to enable the children to learn.
KIPP schools are not for the faint of heart. The school day lasts from 7:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., which allows time for additional classroom work and extracurricular activities. After that there are two hours of homework. The kids also attend classes every other Saturday. And there are three weeks of summer school.
The payoff? KIPP students routinely do better than most of their public school peers. In each of its first seven years the KIPP Academy in Houston has been named a Texas Exemplary School. The students there consistently score among the highest in the annual statewide exams.
For five straight years, the KIPP Academy in the Bronx has outperformed all other public middle schools in the borough in math and reading. The student orchestra, considered one of the finest in the nation, recently performed at Carnegie Hall.
Applicants to KIPP schools are chosen by lottery. The program does not seek out the so-called top students. Several of the kids at Gaston Prep are special education students. But in its short tenure, the school has thrived. In the year before they attended Gaston, only 53 percent of the first class of fifth-graders had passed the North Carolina statewide reading test. After one year at Gaston, 93 percent passed, including 82 percent of the special education students. Gaston Prep is already the highest performing public school in all of the four counties from which its students are drawn.
I don't know how easy it would be to repeat KIPP's early success on a massive scale. With so much work involved, I wonder how much of a commitment could be secured from parents in general, or from teachers in general, or students in general. Young Paris Gatling was not kidding when he said, "We work hard."
The hard work was exactly what Mike Feinberg and Dave Levin, two Teach for America alumni, had in mind when they created KIPP in 1995. "We are never going to end the day shrugging our shoulders and making excuses," said Mr. Feinberg. "If there's a problem, if something is impeding the success of our kids, that needs to be solved one way or another."
Long hours. Hard work. Discipline. Like I said, I don't know how easily that gets replicated. But schools that thrive in the inner city and in poor rural areas deserve, at the very least, some very close attention.

HEADLINE: Market Booms While Zimbabwe Prepares for the Bust 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe, Dec. 13 

 BODY:
The ministers tending Zimbabwe's ailing economy have proposed a quick-fix remedy of price controls, wage freezes and the creation of collective farms, even though price controls are exacerbating food shortages, and a chaotic land redistribution program has devastated commercial agriculture.
 Meanwhile, hundreds of companies have gone broke, unemployment is soaring, and the country is teetering at the edge of famine. 
 So, with the economy in shambles, why is business booming at the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange?
In recent months, the market has reached record heights. This year, while the economy was contracting by about 12 percent, the stock exchange's market capitalization was doubling, surging to its highest level since it was established in 1896. 
What's more, sales of middle-income and luxury homes in the country's wealthy suburbs are surging. People with cash are snapping up televisions, luxury cars and stereos.
The paradox stems from distortions in the controlled economy.
With inflation at more than 144 percent and currency values plummeting, Zimbabweans are putting their money into assets they believe will increase in value -- stocks, real estate, foreign currency, even refrigerators -- rather than bank accounts.
The government has kept interest rates low, so borrowing has been relatively cheap. And these days, many Zimbabweans are buying whatever they can, betting that they can sell the items later at a higher price, often on the black market.
"It's unbelievable, absolutely unbelievable," said Emmanuel Munyukwi, the chief executive of the Zimbabwe Stock Exchange. "People think there's no economy in Zimbabwe. It's actually embarrassing when you have to tell them that we're doing very, very well."
The contradictions abound. While supermarkets routinely run out of bread, milk and sugar, the city's most expensive restaurants are packed, offering imported seafood and wines. Mercedes-Benzes cruise on potholed roads with broken street lights. Houses on prosperous tree-lined streets are selling quickly, and real estate brokers are scrambling to keep up with the demand.
"People are not necessarily buying houses to live in," said Patson Mtare, a broker whose company has sold about 200 houses this year, compared with 100 houses in a normal year. "People are buying to sell."
People with access to foreign currency are buying even more.
The government insists that $1 is equivalent to 57 Zimbabwe dollars, even though $1 goes for as much as 1,600 Zimbabwe dollars on the black market these days. So even some government officials ignore the official exchange rate and change money on the street to make huge profits.
Callisto Jonkonya, who manufactures and exports refrigerators, has bought a new house and several apartments. Raymond Chamba, who runs an employment agency in the United States, bought one 52-inch television, three 43-inch flat-screen televisions and a DVD player all in one day.
He carried his cash in a suitcase.
"Serious money you don't keep in the bank in Zimbabwe," said Mr. Chamba, who has spent the last six months with family in Zimbabwe. "My televisions, they're my bank here."
Most Zimbabweans, however, are too poor to hoard televisions or cars. Over the last three years, the economy has contracted by more than 20 percent. More than 500 companies have closed. Unemployment stands at 60 percent. Most struggling citizens wait for hours in long lines to buy scarce gasoline or bread.
The combination of drought and land reform has left about 6 million people -- roughly half the population -- in need of emergency food aid. Foreign donors have contributed food but refuse to offer financial assistance to the government, which has condoned violence and land seizures.
President Robert Mugabe insists that his controlled economic policy will fix the problem. He has called on the police to crack down on hoarding and black market sales.
But Finance Minister Herbert Murerwa disagreed with this strategy last month when he told Parliament that price controls were leading to "shortages of critical basic necessities on the formal market" because they failed to address the rising costs of production.
Mr. Murerwa said black-market dealers were the chief beneficiaries of price controls, while the poor were suffering. The government has acknowledged that corrupt officials are hoarding and then selling price-controlled goods on the black market.
There are few indications, however, that Mr. Mugabe plans to change course.
So Mr. Munyukwi has decided to delay the celebration for his stock exchange's success.
"It's very difficult to celebrate when your country is hungry," he said. "The stock market is supposed to reflect what's happening in the economy. But we know our economy is in shambles."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
A Family of 5 Struggles To Deal With Traumas Of Sept. 11, With Help

BYLINE:  By ARTHUR BOVINO

 BODY:
The night of Sept. 10, 2001, Pedro Pichardo worked overtime cleaning the stairwells in the north tower of the World Trade Center to prepare for an inspection. The next morning, he was exhausted; he did not feel like going to his job at American Building Maintenance, where he had worked for 13 years. 
 "Go by yourself," he told his wife, Manuela, 35, who had started working there three weeks before. 
 "She said, 'If you're not going, I'm not going,' " Mr. Pichardo, 36, recalled. 
In the end, though, they went to work together. 
And together, they survived the collapse of those towers.
And together, they are now struggling to keep their family from crumbling, too.
When the couple arrived at the trade center at 7:30 that morning, their focus was on their jobs, on the daily routine. Mrs. Pichardo punched in and went to work. Mr. Pichardo did, too, and was assigned to pick up trash on the 58th floor of the south tower. 
But as he boarded an elevator, "something shook it, " he said.
"When I went out I saw a lot of people looking out the window of a conference room," he said. "The only thing that came to my mind was to find Manuela."
Mrs. Pichardo was on the 81st floor of the south tower. As the first plane struck, she was looking through a window at the city and the north tower in quiet introspection, waiting for her assignment.
"You know, you always like to take a look at the city," she said in her native Spanish. "I just saw something going so fast, and suddenly, smoke."
She took the elevator to the 78th floor, where a security guard told her to go back. But she was too shaken. She continued her escape by the stairs. At every floor, three or four people joined her. They were jumping from the tops of the stairwell to the bottom. She was thrown to the floor, hurt her ankle and dislocated her toes.
"The first thing I thought was that I was going to die there and leave my kids," she said.
But she managed to stand and the force of the growing crowd carried her down. 
Meanwhile, with the service elevators full, Mr. Pichardo took the stairs. Somewhere between the 37th and 30th floors, he felt the building shake again. 
For 15 excruciating minutes, he waited at the PATH train for his wife. He waited while the throngs of people diminished. Soon, the grim news began to spread: the buildings were falling down. Losing hope, Mr. Pichardo fled. The force of the collapse threw him to the ground; he was unaware that as his wife was rushing out, the building was falling behind her. 
Independently the Pichardos made their way back to Brooklyn, Mrs. Pichardo to her brother's home, Mr. Pichardo to pick up their children from a baby sitter. They didn't talk on the phone, didn't know if the other was living or dead, until 9 that night.
These are the couple's memories of 9/11. They can't be forgotten. But together, they are trying to put them a safe distance in the past.
Their worker's compensation and disability started in February of this year. Mr. Pichardo now receives $400 a week and his wife receives $270.28 a week. Before that, Mr. Pichardo also received small sums of aid from various groups -- $250 from the Salvation Army, $700 from the Red Cross. They were also eligible for a one-time allotment of $2,500 from Safe Horizons, a nonprofit victim assistance agency.
But both lost their jobs and both are disabled from injuries received in the stairwells. Mr. Pichardo has neck injuries from rolling down the stairs when people panicked. He has a bone chip in his left knee and needs a cane to walk. Mrs. Pichardo's ankle injury makes it painful for her to walk. 
The Pichardos bought their house in Ozone Park, Queens, in May 2000, and a new car soon after. They have three children to provide for: Kristine, 14; Peter, 11; and Algenis, 2. 
Still, it is the emotional trauma that weighs most heavily. She has fainted on the subway. He has had panic attacks between stops. They are afraid to leave their home.
But when the Red Cross directed them to a list of charities, they found the support they needed to overcome the traumas of the last several months. Mr. Pichardo applied for help from the Catholic Charities of Brooklyn and Queens, one of the seven local charities that participate in The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
"At that time we had the 9/11 Neediest Fund," said Rosa Orihuela, the Pichardos' caseworker, referring to the The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund of last year.
With money from the 9/11 fund and the Neediest Cases Fund, Catholic Charities has made three mortgage payments for the Pichardos, $1,864.02 each. It also gave them $956.94 to pay overdue gas and electricity bills. It helped with Kmart gift certificates for toys and clothing for the children, and has assisted the family with $100 in food vouchers and food from the agency's pantry. It has also made two payments totaling $772.72 on the Pichardos' car.
"FEMA is taking on the mortgage payments," said Mrs. Orihuela, who helped with the arrangements. If Mr. Pichardo can recover from surgery before the payments from the Federal Emergency Management Agency end, the Pichardos have a chance of getting their lives back and moving on -- together.
"They helped us a lot more than anybody else," Mr. Pichardo said. "Sometimes I feel bad because it's not easy for me and some other people have a hard time."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PULSE: The South; 
As Post-Boom Dust Settles, The South Grimly Downsizes

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 15 

 BODY:
If the nation boomed in the 1990's, Atlanta exploded.
 Tourism, transportation and technology made its economy a triple threat. Hotels sprang up like jack-in-the-boxes as the city became a leading venue for conventions and trade shows. Business travelers jammed Hartsfield International Airport, pushing it past Chicago's O'Hare Airport as the world's busiest. And with precious little fanfare, Atlanta gained possibly more high-tech jobs than any other city in the nation. 
 But what fueled Atlanta's eye-popping growth in the 1990's has proved the city's economic undoing in the last year and a half. Cuts in business travel before the Sept. 11 attacks emptied Atlanta's hotels. The aftershocks forced Delta Airlines, the city's largest employer, to cut 18,000 jobs nationwide and other airlines to scale back operations here. 
Telecom and Internet companies suffered the same fate as high-tech companies everywhere, causing wrenching readjustments.
Van Black, a 17-year employee of Nortel Networks, moved here from St. Louis with his wife and two children in April 2000 to become a manager in optical networking, then Nortel's hottest division. He lured hundreds of other workers to Atlanta, but by early 2001 most of them had been laid off, and that July so was he. 
"I wish I hadn't moved to this hot thing," Mr. Black says now. "It was literally feast to famine in a couple of months."
Across the South, the economic landscape has turned upside down. Atlanta, where all arrows once pointed up, is hurting most: 61,800 jobs were lost in the 12 months that ended in October -- more than in any other city in the country, according to the federal Department of Labor. And the job losses are continuing. 
Even North Carolina's powerhouse area, Raleigh-Durham, which is normally all but immune to hard times thanks to a largely tenured work force of university and state government employees, has seen its unemployment rate double this year. In Hickory, N.C., and the surrounding area, entire fiber-optic cable factories have been mothballed in recent weeks, and 3,200 jobs have been cut since spring 2001.
In Louisiana, where the oil-and-gas industry typically buoys the state during national recessions, anxieties about a conflict with Iraq appear to have held up new investment -- and job growth.
But in Alabama, Mississippi and Arkansas -- where foreign-owned factories are turning out luxury cars and food processors are churning out products less vulnerable to cyclical pressures -- it is a different story. The economic pain has been less acute. 
The simplest explanation for the regional trends, economists say, is that the most diversified economies, like Georgia's, are suffering along with the nation through the lingering slowdown that has kept prosperity well around the corner.
Elsewhere in the Southeast, manufacturing generally makes up close to 20 percent of employment. But while that sector has been hit hard by the downturn, economists say, it is also likely to pick up quickly once the outlook for business investment brightens.
"This is a recession that's really picked its spots," said John Robertson, senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta. "Diversity's a good thing in the aggregate, but it's not so good if you're in the wrong tail of that diversity distribution. On the other hand, Alabama and Mississippi aren't exactly going like gangbusters, but they never really have."
The hard times are playing havoc with state and local budgets across the country, and the South is no exception. Revenue shortfalls in nearly every Southern state have forced legislatures to cut spending, slow or table construction projects and trim payrolls, though as yet without mass layoffs.
In Tennessee, the only state in the region with no income tax, lawmakers in July approved a penny sales-tax increase to generate $933 million. Not surprisingly, officials everywhere in the region but Tennessee reported concerns or pessimism about declining tax revenue in a survey last month by the National Conference of State Legislatures. 
Brisk auto sales, fueled by low interest rates and zero-percent-financing deals, have held the drop in sales tax receipts to an average of 2.7 percent in 13 Southern states, according to a Georgia State University study. But plummeting corporate profits -- one of the hallmarks of the national slowdown -- resulted in an average shortfall of 14 percent in corporate income tax collections, the study found.
In Georgia alone, for example, state officials said on Dec. 9 that total tax collections were down 5.2 percent for the first five months of the fiscal year, but that corporate income taxes had plunged 38 percent. Altogether the state is running more than $275 million behind tax-revenue estimates.

A Changing View of Growth
For Atlanta, the severity of the downturn may even be affecting the city's self-image.
For decades, though the carcasses of speculative real estate projects periodically piled up along Peachtree Street, this sprawling metropolis seemed to bull its way through bear-market cycles. 
The 1996 Summer Olympics helped immeasurably. Infrastructure and commercial construction projects begun before the Games eased the early-1990's recession and probably sustained the boom for a few more years, said Jeffrey M. Humphries, director of the University of Georgia's Selig Center for Economic Growth. "Unfortunately, we didn't have another Olympics in 2002," Mr. Humphries said.
Atlanta now faces traffic density that the roads and highways cannot handle, threats to air quality, looming water shortages, and -- unfathomable a few years back -- a groundswell of opposition to the city's grow-at-any-cost religion. Mr. Humphries said, "It's being brought about by the stresses of the economic boom we've just gone through, but it's affecting our reputation as a good place to do business."
He added, "Atlanta is just not as hungry for growth as it was even recently."
In some parts of the South, tourism has been slowly picking up again, particularly along the South Carolina coast, where resorts and hotels in places like Charleston, Myrtle Beach and Hilton Head may have benefited from any lingering post-Sept. 11 concerns about air travel or about avoiding big cities that could be terrorist targets.
"I don't think golfers were afraid that terrorists were going to come hit the golf course," said Mark P. Vitner, senior economist at the Wachovia Corporation.
But in Atlanta, where the travel is overwhelmingly business-related and visitors more often than not walk the streets wearing name tags, the slump in corporate profits has been devastating because it has prompted companies to reduce travel expenses.
One in nine of the metropolitan area's jobs are in tourism, transportation and hotels, Mr. Vitner said, and occupancy rates for the city's major convention hotels have fallen to below 60 percent from the high 80's. "These are the lowest vacancy rates since we've been tracking, going back to the early 1960's," he said.
The terrorist attacks put the finishing touches on Atlanta's tourism crash, which has affected everyone, including hotel clerks and taxi drivers, who now wait in lines for hours at the airport and hotels for a single fare.
Northwest Airlines recently said it would close its Atlanta hangar, which employs 1,600 mechanics and other workers.
But the impact on Atlanta has been far greater from the red ink at Delta Airlines, which has lost more than $2 billion in the last seven quarters. Before Delta responded by cutting 18,000 jobs nationally, it was Atlanta's largest employer, with 30,000 workers at its Atlanta headquarters and flight hub. The Atlanta workers made up 44 percent of Delta's payroll.
Fayette County, south of Atlanta, may be absorbing the worst of Delta's woes. As many as 1 in 10 Delta workers live there, many of them in the planned, patrolled, sparkling subdivisions of Peachtree City. One is Grady Boyce, 34, a pilot who moved here with his wife and son in 1998 to better his chances in the airline industry.
It worked, at least for a while. Delta hired him in 2000. But in November 2001, Delta began furloughing pilots, and Mr. Boyce was let go in May. He was the 722nd pilot let go.
Mr. Boyce now has three other mouths to feed -- a wife, a 4-year-old son and a 20-month-old daughter born with birth defects requiring operations and daily therapy -- and he wrestles over whether he ever should have moved to Atlanta. "Depends on the day you ask me," he said.
Mr. Boyce has been looking for a job to tide him over until Delta revives and he can return to flying. But few employers have been receptive. "You start submitting your resume to people and they say, 'What do you do besides fly?' " he said, "and I try to talk about my business and management training, but employers focus on the flying thing. They say, 'You're just a pilot, what could you possibly do for me?' "

Moving In, Losing Jobs
Atlanta was originally a railroad town, and it remains one of the country's five largest distribution centers, with 420 million square feet of industrial space in warehouses lining the three interstates that converge in the city.
But 18.1 million square feet are vacant now, a result of the largest drop in business inventories in history, said Charles B. King Jr., chairman of a leading industrial realty brokerage concern here. "That's more vacant space in Atlanta than the entire market in Jacksonville, Fla.," he said.
"We've had six straight quarters of negative absorption," Mr. King said. "We've never experienced that before. It's much worse than it's ever been. It hurts the truckers, the forklift drivers, the warehouse folks -- that whole distribution arm."
In the same way, Atlanta's real estate market for office space -- which grew to meet the demands of the metropolitan area's many Fortune 500 corporations, fewer only than New York and Chicago -- is now burdened with surplus space available for sublease at below-market rents. 
"It used to be the only time they got into trouble was when they overbuilt real estate," Mr. Vitner said. "Not in this case. This time it was overleased space -- companies that thought they were going to grow like crazy, then they dumped it on the market."
Still, the most poignant illustrations of the downturn are the roughly 20,000 highly skilled but suddenly unemployed workers who were laid off from telecom and technology companies with headquarters or major operations in Atlanta. The companies include Cingular Wireless, WorldCom and Internet Security Systems, and even national consulting concerns like Accenture.
About 150,000 people a year moved to Atlanta in the 1990's. One was Karl W. Gross, 28, who brought his M.B.A. here from Virginia in 1999 and went to work on computer systems for such Accenture clients as Bell South and United Parcel Service. He quickly found himself interacting with top-level executives and earning enough money to buy a condo and a BMW.
But even as Accenture was about to go public, Mr. Gross recalled, he and other junior employees read the news of falling stock prices with growing unease. 
"It was just a matter of time before some of these companies said, 'We'd love to keep you guys but we have to cut back,' " he said. "There were signs. I remember at Bell South one day, they said you can't use the color copier."
Mr. Gross lost his job in August in Accenture's second round of layoffs, and figured he would land a new position quickly. He is still looking -- doggedly, using 15 headhunters and checking a half-dozen Web sites daily.
"It's been a smack in the face that, hey, this is the way things are," Mr. Gross said. "I know how this works; companies do not want to hire you around the holidays for a lot of reasons. So I've got my fingers crossed that in January some jobs will start to open up."
One job application led to a surreal outing, he said, when a recruiter sent him to check out a prospective job. He shadowed a commission-only saleswoman for a company hired by Bell South -- Mr. Gross's former client -- as she knocked on doors in Gainesville, Ga., hoping to persuade people to switch their telephone service.
"There would be churches that were, like, locked and she'd try to kind of break in, thinking there might be somebody inside who could want service," he said, chuckling. "You see what bad times do to people."
Now, Mr. Gross drives his BMW to the state unemployment office, and he looks differently at Atlanta's street people. "Now I see them and I think, wow, I'm about four, five, six months away from potentially being in that position," he said.

Riding on Auto Sales
Georgia's economy lives or dies with Atlanta's. The capital city and surrounding counties account for 55 percent of the state's jobs. Elsewhere in the South, no other city or region is as important to a state's economy, as the nation's financial woes have hit some places with fury and barely affected others. 
Perhaps the best example of this is in the automobile industry, which has brought assembly lines and thousands of jobs to once-poor parts of Alabama, South Carolina, Tennessee and Mississippi. Georgia, Arkansas and Louisiana are seeking to join that group, but no Southern state has missed the auto industry's expansion entirely. 
One recent study of the BMW plant that South Carolina won in 1992 after offering $150 million in incentives revealed that neighboring North Carolina had actually received more of the resulting benefits, in jobs and contracts for auto suppliers.
With interest rates low, homeowners across the country have been refinancing mortgages and using the proceeds to buy new cars and other durable goods, experts say. That has helped those auto plants.
More than any state, Alabama has been buoyed by the auto industry in recent years, with Honda and Mercedes factories already open and Hyundai and Toyota plants in the works. 
Gary Shoesmith, director of Wake Forest University's Center for Economic Studies, said Alabama was doubly fortunate in that the makes and models of the cars rolling off the assembly lines in the state have been fairly immune from the downturn. "The people that lose their jobs aren't buying Mercedes," Mr. Shoesmith said.
But auto plants are hardly a panacea. Tennessee, which makes Saturn and Nissan cars and Peterbilt trucks, has increasingly mirrored the auto industry's cyclical fortunes, said Matthew N. Murray, an economic forecaster at the University of Tennessee. 
"We really welcomed the auto industry when it moved down here, suppliers and all, but we're paying a bit of a price," Mr. Murray said. "Despite what's going on in auto sales, both the state and the nation are losing jobs in transportation equipment, because of cost-cutting and efficiency, and cutthroat competition on the supply chain."
Indeed, the transportation employment picture in Tennessee improved this year, but it was hardly cause for celebration. The year-to-year decline in transportation jobs went to 1.8 percent from 7.5 percent.
"We're still in the red," Mr. Murray said. "I'm not sure I'm feeling any better about it -- I'm starving to death, I'm losing weight -- I'm just not losing as much weight as I was last week?"
Like other economists, Mr. Murray questioned whether the nation's torrid auto sales could continue much longer, or whether most new car buyers had already made their purchases, lured by low interest rates and financing incentives. 
"The concern I have is the dramatic sale of new cars in the last year, and what that means for auto sales the next couple of years," he said. "What does the future hold when every garage has got a new car in it?"

CORRECTION-DATE: January 11, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 16 about the economy in the Southeast included an erroneous reference to a study of the economic impact of a BMW auto plant in South Carolina. The study, by the Moore School of Business at the University of South Carolina in 2002, showed that BMW's investment supported 16,691 jobs and produced $691 million in annual wages and salaries in South Carolina. The study did not examine the benefits to North Carolina and did not show that North Carolina received more jobs and contracts for auto suppliers than South Carolina received.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
Living Under the Virtual Volcano of Video Games This Holiday Season

BYLINE:  By VERLYN KLINKENBORG 

 BODY:
Playboy Magazine has yet to do a pictorial called "Women of the Xbox," starring characters that appear in video games running on Microsoft's popular game console. But in its newest issue, Play Magazine features a double-page screen shot taken from a new video game called "DOA Extreme Beach Volleyball." The photo spread shows a bikini-clad young woman whose face, in its Stepford-like innocence, seems contradicted somehow by the remarkable authority of her body. Technophiles and sophisticated gamers have been marveling at the software engineering that has gone into making such a sublime creation. Then their eyes snap back into focus and they simply marvel. She was once a deadly fighter in a previous version of the game. Now she and her colleagues play volleyball -- realistic volleyball -- for the masses. The player gets to choose the swimwear. 
 It's no wonder that this season marks another pinnacle in video game revenues, on the order of $10 billion in 2002. The degree of realism and fantasy -- and demented irony -- in video games has never been higher. But ever since the days, 20-some years ago, when the Atari 2600 took over living rooms across the country, Americans have been crazy for video games. Just how crazy is captured by a few numbers. Some 145 million Americans now play video games regularly, in arcades, on personal computers or on so-called next generation consoles like Sony's PlayStation 2, Nintendo's GameCube or Microsoft's Xbox. According to industry analysts, the average age of a modern gamer is 28, and slightly more than half of them are men. These numbers are only likely to grow larger as the world of video games moves online. 
 But what matters even more than the size of the video game world is its depth and complexity. It's a world where time has been captured, where nearly every console or game cartridge lives on in one form or another, as a venerable relic being sold on eBay or as an emulation for modern computers. If you plunge into the gaming world you discover a riot of hardware platforms and software influences, a jabber of languages deriving from a hundred mythical worlds, as well as from the lexicon of game programming and game marketing itself. 
The imaginative and economic power of the leading game designers has had a profound effect on Hollywood, and for good reason. The depth of illusion in the newest games is truly cinematic. Each of this season's blockbuster movie franchises -- Harry Potter, James Bond, J. R. R. Tolkien -- is spawning a video game, as is nearly every other movie with a plausible action theme. If you're a serious gamer, it's hard to go to the movies without reaching around for the game controller, without feeling as if you're stuck watching a one-way plot. 
But if you've played any of the new-generation video games -- titles like "Splinter Cell" or "Blinx the Time Sweeper" or almost anything else released in the past year or two -- you quickly realize that they create a sense of perceptual reality that is far more intense than anything the movies offer. No matter how much a movie absorbs you, you never really break the plane of the movie screen. But if they're about anything, video games now are about breaking the plane, taking the player into a world whose dimensions you can feel, almost as if they were real, when you close your eyes. Gamers are forever talking about the intricacies of those worlds, the qualities of the game-play, the subtleties of the rendering, the raw imagination on display. But what underlies it all is that visceral sense of having walked through a door into another universe. 
And that, of course, is precisely what troubles critics of video games. A good number of the doors you walk through lead to mayhem of the worst kind, to what the Entertainment Software Rating Board, which rates each game, calls "Animated Blood" or "Gore" or "Strong Sexual Content." These are universes where no one dies a natural death, where limbs fly and heads erupt, and the women -- well-armed heroines, many of them --are drawn by men who have mastered the art of what the industry calls "breast physics." No game is inherently amoral, because the play of the game imposes its own self-contained rules on how behavior is rewarded. But a game like "Grand Theft Auto: Vice City" or the notorious "BMX XXX" certainly qualifies as amoral by any real-world standards. 
In a way, nothing can teach you more about the modern obsession with entertainment than a sojourn in the world of video games. The best of them take hours of practice to get good at, and they contain hundreds of hours of play once you do get good. The real question is always, "What are you getting good at?," and "virtual volleyball" just doesn't seem like answer enough. But there are at least two good answers to that question, neither of them very satisfying to critics. The first is that every human activity, serious or playful, eventually ramifies into a world of its own, a self-contained cosmos of enormous complexity. The other answer is $10 billion.

HEADLINE: Trade Center Site, Round 2: New Designs to Be Unveiled Wednesday 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT

 BODY:
When seven teams of architects unveil their designs for the World Trade Center site on Wednesday, the public will be treated to a unusual seminar on innovative design and architecture that is rarely a part of normal civic life.
 A news conference to introduce the designs -- a three-hour presentation, to be broadcast live on local television and edited into a videotape that will be available at every public library in the city -- will include discourses from the architects themselves, models of their work and drawings of views from the tops of buildings and upon emerging from the subway. 
 The plans themselves "present a dazzling diversity of geometric configurations, ranging from conventional building shapes to highly unorthodox structural forms," said John C. Whitehead, chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.
Yet for all their certainty about the success of the designs, rebuilding officials and professionals in architecture and urban design are concerned about how the public will decide which ones it likes -- and whether it will ignore considerations of architecture and urban design in favor of a simplistic beauty contest. 
Which raises the question, how are citizens who might not know or care much about the difference between urban design and architecture supposed to look at these models? How does a viewer translate a scale rendering into a perception of what it would be like to stand within this new streetscape, for example, or make sense of why one concept might work while another would not?
The key is to "try to imagine living in the space," said Marcie Kesner, an architect and co-chairwoman of New York New Visions, a group of architecture and design firms that worked with the development corporation in organizing the current round of designs. "Try to imagine yourself walking through these streets or trying to get from one part of Lower Manhattan to another," she said. "Visualize what that experience might be like."
Rather than just looking at the designs of buildings, or being enchanted by spinning models or subtle watercolors, Ms. Kesner said, "think about where the cars are going to go, or how the spaces connect to the surrounding neighborhoods." And do not be intimidated by a lack of formal training. After all, she said, "in New York, all of us to an extent are experts in urban living."
It is a difficult challenge that some architects doubt the public is up to. 
"What the public understands is pretty pictures," Hugh Hardy, a New York architect, said recently at a symposium in Lower Manhattan sponsored by the American Institute of Architects. "It's extraordinary to see how visually illiterate the public at large is and how dependent they are on renderings."
"That's a problem that has run through this whole process," added Mr. Hardy, whose firm, Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer, oversaw the restoration of Radio City Music Hall. "We've got to help and bridge the gap between what the public expects as a language and what, in fact, the issues are."
The development corporation's vice president for planning, design and development, Alexander Garvin, who oversaw the design competition, said that although Mr. Hardy's comments might be blunt, they could not be ignored. "But I have faith in the public," Mr. Garvin added. "I think the public came back the last time we put things out and was incredibly perceptive in what they wanted and didn't want."
Rebuilding officials concede that they will be fighting against their experience with the first set of designs, which was released in July and quickly derided as ugly and uninspiring. Those designs were what architects and designers call "massing models," layouts that show where buildings sit but do not try to define what the buildings themselves would look like.
"We're not going to make that mistake again," said Roland W. Betts, a director of the development corporation who has overseen the board's site-planning committee. "There is going to be a higher level of articulation in these designs."
And while the development corporation intentionally gave those previous designs a uniform look, Mr. Garvin said of the new designs, "I think you will be quite amazed at how different one is from the next."
Some people who have been active in the public discussion about rebuilding Lower Manhattan say that the public must look harder at the broader implications of the designs for the trade center site.
"I'm sure there are going to be plenty of beautiful forms and shapes," said David Kallick, a senior fellow at the Fiscal Policy Institute and a coordinator of the Labor Community Advocacy Network to Rebuild New York. "But what's important is not just what the site is going to look like, but what it is going to do to the economy and what it is going to do for the city."
Mr. Kallick said that the fact that the designs were being unveiled just before many people went on vacation for the end-of-year holidays was likely to make it more difficult than usual to get adequate, informed public participation. Viewers should also recognize that anything planned for the site will be phased in over several years, during which the site will be part of an active community. The architects were asked, therefore, to preview what the site would look like in 2 or 5 or 10 years.
In total, the seven teams have produced nine plans for the trade center site, which will be on display at the Winter Garden in the World Financial Center from Friday through Feb. 3. The designs will also be on the development corporation's Web site, www.renewnyc.org, and comments can be submitted at both places. 
Raymond W. Gastil, executive director of the Van Alen Institute, a nonprofit center for architecture that is named for the designer of the Chrysler Building, said viewers should be aware that what they saw in the designs was still not intended to be exactly what would be built.
Those decisions are years away, he said, although the drawings are likely to be experiential. "They will show you, for example, that this is the central square," Mr. Gastil said, "and this is what it is like to be in the central square. Or this is what it is like to be in this tower."
As such, viewers should first consider the renderings by taking them at face value. "That's the question -- would these plans make a place where people actually want to be?" Mr. Gastil said. "Is that a special enough place to go to live or to work or to play? It requires using one's imagination as to what the experience of being there would be."
Second, viewers should consider the designs' more technical aspects -- if a rendering shows a sunny, lovely square, for example, is it surrounded by 800-foot towers that will make it a gloomy, dismal place?
One way to consider those aspects, Mr. Gastil said, is to compare the redesigned trade center site with other well-known public places in the city with similar attributes, like Times Square or Union Square or Fifth Avenue at 59th Street.
Finally, Mr. Gastil said, consider the designs' poetics -- does it create an icon for the skyline, for example? If a design calls for an important public space on the 100th floor, will it realistically be like what the designer imagines? 
"It's hard to know exactly what works and what doesn't," Mr. Gastil said. "But you can use common sense. Imagine going from this point to that point to get on the train." 
The seven groups of architects were instructed not to design the memorial that will be built at the site but simply to plan for it, and some plans are likely to be more extensive than others. 
Many people have asked whether the memorial will be separated from the surrounding commercial areas, and what a person will experience approaching the memorial. Can it be entered from anywhere else on the site, for example, or does it require passage through a sort of ceremonial entrance so that the experience is relatively similar for all visitors?
Rebuilding officials have not shied away from raising expectations about the plans or their unveiling this week, and while no plans will satisfy every viewer, Mr. Garvin said he thought that most people would be pleasantly surprised.
"As a piece of theater and as an inspirational day," he said of the day the designs will first be presented to the public, "you probably are not going to have a day like this again in your life."
